Madam Speaker, I did not advocate, as the member said, scrapping all agreements with the United States. I talked about the FTA and the North American free trade agreement.
The member does point out, quite rightly, that the bind that the country has been put in with respect to our relationship with the United States by this agreement, because what he is trying to do is imply that if we were to get out of these agreements, the form of American retaliation might be, for instance, the cancelling of the auto pact. I presume that is what he suggests.
This is why it was so misleading for the Prime Minister to say in 1988: "Well, it is just a commercial agreement; if we don't like it we will just get out of it".
I tried to be honest in my own remarks about the consequences of getting out of it; the consequences of it could be nasty. I said that. I tried to say that Canadians will have to make that choice. They will have to choose between the difficulty of staying in the agreement and the difficulty of being out of it. I say we choose the difficulty of being out of it. That is fair enough. I want to know what difficulty you choose.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is a little hard to know from the tone of the conversation so far, but this is a serious debate we are undertaking here today. The continued success of our trade performance is critical to our future prosperity as a nation. I think every Canadian from coast to coast to coast has a stake in the export success of our entrepreneurs and that is why this government from the day it took office has placed international trade at the top of its agenda.
We have pursued a strategy aimed at making Canada an international competitor worthy of the tough global economy that we have today. I emphasize "global" and I emphasize "today".
We do not live in the past, nor do we intend to. We cannot lift the drawbridge and keep the world out. We have faith in the ability of Canadian companies to compete with known rules of the game. That is really what this is about. To be successful our trade strategy must reflect the realities of today's global economy and Canada's place in it. Regretfully there is no room for romantic and fanciful delusions based on past or imagined successes.
The resolution before us today gives the illusion of promoting a global strategy, but at heart it is a council of despair. It seeks a world that simply does not exist, a world that would ignore the realities of geography, a world that would not recognize the benefits of foreign investment, a world that would tear up our trade agreements, isolate us from our principal trading partners; a world that would turn its back on the achievements of the past, as emphasized by the comments from my colleague from Mississauga, and leave us naked before the challenges of tomorrow.
This government's approach to international market development, to international trade negotiations and to international trade relations has been based on the fundamental premise that Canada is a global trading nation, no more, no less. It also recognizes that we live next door to the richest and most advanced economy on earth. Other countries would give their eye teeth to be so blessed. It is not an unmixed blessing, as we know so well, but surely it is a blessing and let us not believe otherwise.
The United States is our best customer and we are theirs. Last year alone we did $256 billion worth of business between the two countries. No other countries come close to that. It is quality business. It is not just rocks and logs but it is cars and computers. It is software and engineering contracts. It is satellites and subway cars. It is flight simulators and wing assemblies. The Japanese would love to do that much business, so would the Mexicans and the Europeans and indeed, everyone else; except it seems members opposite.
March 13, 1992

They would tear up the agreement that provides the security for trade, the agreement that furnishes the framework of rules and procedures that gives Canadians the confidence to take on tough markets, the agreement that provides the foundation for two million jobs in Canada.
Our appreciation of that agreement and the trade it represents should not be misled by focusing entirely on irritants. Such irritants are not a sign of weakness but the result of strength. They are a recognition by American interests that we are successful traders. That does not make them easier to accept. These trade disputes sting but it should at least give us some perspective on this whole issue.
Five per cent of our exports to the United States are affected by the current list of irritants. We do not like that number. We do not like the irritants but we have to reduce the number. We have to remember also that 95 per cent of the trade is flowing freely, exactly as we would like.
We are confident with respect to the irritants that right is on our side. Tearing up the agreement would place the 95 per cent at risk. How is that for a great trade strategy? Who would benefit from such a flight from reality? To compound the error of tearing up the FTA, the resolution would have Canada walk away from the NAFTA negotiations.
And the GATT.

And the GATT, as my colleague says. Not only would the resolution ensure a trade war with the United States, it would tell Canada and by implication our Latin American trading partners that we are not prepared to work with them, that we are no longer interested in creating a trading future based on a framework of stable and orderly rules. Make no mistake, that is what the NAFTA negotiations are all about and that is what we would turn our back on.
The GATT world trade talks are an integral and critical element in Canada's trade strategy. It is neither an alternative to nor unrelated to the FTA or the NAFTA. They are all a concerted effort by Canada and its trading partners to create a more ordered and more predictable global trading system. Each is an effort to strengthen the rules, to improve procedures to resolve disputes and to bind nations to a common approach to the regulation of trade and investment.
Supply
For Canada, the success of these negotiations is critically important. It will help us gain and defend access to the markets of the world, including the United States and Mexico. In other words, we have not placed our eggs in a single basket, rather we are defending and promoting Canadian trade interests wherever there is an opportunity to do so.
I just came back from an OECD meeting of science and technology ministers having to do with the economy and growth. The whole meeting, with governments of every stripe, concentrated on how we can all be more prosperous, how we can all trade with each other, how we can all have economies of benefit if we have the rules of the game clearly spelled out. That is what this is all about.
Our trade with the United States is important, but so is our trade with the rest of the world.
In 1991, our trade with all of our trading partners totalled $381.6 billion; that is one-quarter of our Gross Domestic Product. Trade with countries other than the United States totalled $124.7 billion. You have to remember that merchandise exports of $34.1 billion translate into more than a million jobs for Canadians. Our merchandise trade with countries other than the United States is growing. Our global approach has been instrumental in a 5 per cent annual growth in that trade since we took office.
Those numbers are the result of Canada's multi-faceted, global trade strategy. Canadian entrepreneurs know that wherever they go they can count on the support of Canada's 1,060 trade commissioners. They know where to find them at 90 offices across the world, at headquarters and at international trade centres across Canada. They know they can rely on hundreds of agreements that Canada has negotiated to smooth their way: air agreements, double tax agreements, economic co-operation agreements, investment agreements, export financing agreements.
Canadian exporters know that they can draw on the support programs developed to assist their marketing efforts: the Program for Export Market Development (PEMD), trade fairs and missions, the Strategic Ventures Program, Going Global, CIDA Inc., the EDC and more.
There is probably not a member in this House who has not used one or more of those programs to promote trade in their own constituency. It is interesting that

March 13, 1992
when it comes to their home constituencies, they want Canada to be an international trading partner and they want Canada to have these kinds of programs which promote their own constituency, but when it gets to the global enterprise, somehow or another they cannot quite manage to grasp the significance of what is being done.
The programs that I have mentioned do not cater to the multinational corporate elite, as you would have believed from listening to the comments earlier. They are for Canadian companies large and small. They are for companies that are found right across Canada; Halifax, Guelph, Gravelburg, Saskatchewan. They employ your neighbours and mine. Our programs are not just for big companies, they are for all Canadian companies.
Our strategy for trade starts at home. We will not be successful traders abroad unless we are successful competitors at home.
I have travelled across this country in the last two years, talking about what we need to do to be a competitive nation, telling the people about the use of technology and how it will help us in terms of economic growth, giving facts and figures of the difficulties as I see them and there has been a response. The whole prosperity initiative is based upon these kinds of discussions with Canadians from coast to coast. They do not want us to rip up the FTA. They want us to continue our discussions with NAFTA. They understand that Canada is a trading nation and must remain so.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Unfortunately, I will have to interrupt the hon. minister. He will have a little more than eight minutes remaining when we resume debate.

Madam Speaker, yesterday there was a collision between a British Columbia ferry and a Japanese bulk coal carrier off Roberts Bank which is located in my riding of Delta.
The 17 injured passengers were taken to Delta hospital for acute emergency care. Although the hospital only has 75 acute care beds, because it is on many major transportation links and the only hospital south of the Fraser River it has developed an excellent emergency and disaster control program.
This hospital had also handled several casualties from the fatal bus crash on Highway 99 the day before and these casualties had strained the bed situation. In spite of that they handled the emergencies very well yesterday.
I would like to commend the paramedics involved in transporting the injured as well as the administrator, the nursing staff and my former medical colleagues at the Delta hospital for a job well done in bringing good care and comfort to those injury victims. Their planning, practice and expertise has once again paid off in an excellent way.

Madam Speaker, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs has considerably angered Quebecers by recently suggesting that they would lose their Canadian citizenship if Quebec separates.
In the first place, ministers of the government should not speculate on what might happen as a result of any sovereignty referendum.
Second, the minister is absolutely wrong with respect to the law. At present Canadian law permits dual citizenship. One can be a Canadian and at the same time an American. One can be a Canadian and an Italian.
Furthermore, one can live for a considerable period of time in another country and still retain one's Canadian citizenship.
The only way a Canadian can lose his or her citizenship is by deliberately renouncing it. Obviously, those who vote for Quebec separation would want to do that. But those who do not will have every right to retain this important heritage. Quebecers are worried enough about the situation in their province and do not need unnecessary speculation to upset them even more.
March 13, 1992

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, virtually all Canadians are understandably proud of medicare and the quality of health care which it provides on a universal basis.
Consequently, we are shocked and dismayed when American politicians, as they do on occasion, criticize medicare for what they claim to be its shortcomings.
You can imagine how surprised and angered Canadians would be, therefore, if they had had the opportunity to read the February 27, 1992 edition of The Brandon Sun and to discover that a Canadian politician speaking in Neepawa, Manitoba, in fact the leader of the Reform Party, had promised to abolish medicare as a universal program.
Perhaps the leader of the Reform Party who is the son of a Social Credit premier undoubtedly enjoyed a privileged upbringing and does not understand the importance of medicare to ordinary Canadians of all ages and particularly to seniors.
Perhaps he does not understand, therefore, that Canadians will not permit any politician or any party, including those whose roots are in the distant past to destroy medicare as we know it.

Madam Speaker, I was extremely disappointed that neither the Conservative Party nor the New Democratic Party members of the Special Joint Committee on a Renewed Canada, better known as the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee of which I was a member, would support the Liberal Party's request to have a strong and effective Senate by ensuring that the Senate's decisions could not be overridden or could not easily be overridden by the House of Commons. If you are going to reform the Senate, surely it must among other things, be effective.
The Liberal Party members registered their dissent on this point on page 55 of the committee report which reads:
"Liberal members-disagree with the majority recommendation concerning the powers of the Senate because of the proposed override of a Senate veto of legislation. Such an override, and it was a simple override, will undermine the effectiveness of the Senate-Therefore, the Liberal members of the committee recommend that a reformed Senate be granted an absolute veto on all bills, except for appropriation and budget bills."

Madam Speaker, International Women's Week is over but double discrimination continues against women of colour and immigrant women.
Domestic workers are locked into live-in jobs where they can be exploited and new policies will exclude many women of colour from coming to Canada as domestics.
Lack of professional accreditation forces many immigrant women to remain in low-paying jobs.
The Tory budget also has added another layer of hardship for these women. The $1 million cut to Canada Jobs Strategy training represents a 35 per cent cut to immigrant women who also lack child care.
Payments owing for pay equity are denied women public servants.
The Court Challenges Program which gave women of colour a chance to achieve equality rights through our courts is cancelled.
The legislated Race Relations Foundation to fight racism is indefinitely postponed.
This government has lost all respect for the rights of minorities, and especially for women of colour who are doubly jeopardized.

Madam Speaker, my constituents continue to offer me some excellent advice and comment.
Ron Fotheringham of Bolton, Ontario writes: "We should enact a simple vocabulary change. We should remove the word 'government' from our vocabulary and substitute the word 'taxpayer' in some cases 'taxpayers representatives'. It changes all our headlines and makes one re-think concepts like, 'The federal government today contributed Y-million dollars to the purchase of de

Havilland'; 'Metro government calls upon the federal government for aid in covering welfare payments to refugees'; 'Your provincial government will ask the federal government for help in these tough economic times'. I have been replacing 'government' with 'taxpayer' in what I hear, read and say. The impact of this vocabulary change is truly amazing. Try it yourself for a week."
And finally, John Benitz of Belfountain, Ontario, simply sends this message: "The silent majority want a united Canada. We also want Canada to be a privilege to enter as an immigrant and not a right. We want to afford our social programs and not burden our children with our debt."
Thank you, Madam Speaker, for this opportunity to air my constituents' views.

Madam Speaker, I would like to draw the attention of all hon. members to a recent survey by Chatelaine magazine which names Sussex, New Brunswick, which is located in my riding of Fundy-Royal, as being one of the top 10 towns to live in in Canada.
Sussex, considered by some to be the quintessential rural community, offers its residents the opportunity to ski the slopes of Poley Mountain, enjoy the splendour and magnificent sights of Fundy National Park on a year-long basis, and participate in the many festivals offered throughout the year.
If that were not enough to make one live in Sussex, it also enjoys a sound agricultural base, two potash mines and several food and dairy processors to maintain the 90 per cent regional employment rate.
I know that all members of this House will want to join with me in congratulating Sussex on being named one of the top 10 towns to live in.

Madam Speaker, Canadian consumers are being ripped off by paying for pollution controls that are being damaged by the fuel additive MMT, that may also be putting the health of this nation at risk.
The average new car purchased in Canada costs $16,790. Ford Canada says newer model cars will require an additional $800 worth of emission control devices to meet the green plan's new hydrocarbon emission standards.
Yet as the United States Environmental Protection Agency states in their final notice rejecting the use of MMT in the United States in unleaded fuel for the fourth time: "Ford concluded that the data clearly show that MMT impairs to a significant degree the performance of emission control devices."
The EPA also noted:
"Toyota also submitted data indicating that the efficiency at which the catalyst was operating for the MMT-exposed components was less than that for the non-MMT exposed components."
The green plan emission standards are fraudulent as long as MMT is allowed in Canadian fuel. I call on the government to examine the U.S. EPA decision, the Ford and Toyota evidence, and to replace MMT with the environmentally friendly alternative, ethanol.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the Canadian land border duty free program provides a valuable source of revenue to the federal government and the border communities. It creates employment and promotes tourism and national identity through the sale of Canadian manufactured products.
Members of the industry, however, insist that they are unintended victims of the government's plan to levy an excise tax on all exports of Canadian tobacco products.
The purpose of the tax is to combat tobacco smuggling. However, studies have failed to make any connection between our tobacco smuggling problem and duty free shops.
The land border duty free shops account for less than 11 per cent of the export market, yet tobacco sales make up over 50 per cent of their total sales. Our duty free shops rely heavily on these sales as catch lines for travellers and tourists.
March 13, 1992

The industry is prepared to discuss and suggest proposals to relieve anxieties about cross-border shopping and smuggling. I urge the government to accept this invitation and to consult with the land border duty free industry toward a mutually acceptable solution.

Wilson Ne-poose spent over five years in jail for a murder conviction based on questionable evidence.
Last year the Minister of Justice, under section 690 of the Criminal Code ordered an appeal for Wilson Ne-poose. In its recent decision, the Alberta Court of Appeal overturned his conviction and ordered a new trial.
The appeal court found that the evidence presented to Wilson Nepoose's original trial was deficient. In fact, it has been suggested that the evidence indicating Wilson Nepoose's guilt was, in some cases, fabricated or coerced and in other cases the Crown withheld evidence which supported his innocence.
I call on the Minister of Justice and the Solicitor General to strike a full formal inquiry into the Nepoose murder investigation to find out who fabricated, coerced or withheld evidence and recommend appropriate action.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
It was not
enough last week that our closest ally and trading partner attacked us. Now it turns out that two members of the NDP have been systematically betraying and slandering the B.C. share groups that represent our resource-based communities.
Share groups are not anti-environment. Our share groups are integral elements of the communities throughout British Columbia. They represent and try to balance the interests of all stakeholders of our forests and our environment.
The membership does include people who work in the forest industry, but they also include others, mayors, teachers, businessmen and ranchers. This is truly a grassroots organization.
Twice stabbed in the back is too much. It is one thing to receive it from the U.S., but it is quite another to have the workers of B.C. attacked by their so-called friends. The communities of Cariboo-Chilcotin will not soon forget this betrayal by the NDP members of Skeena and Comox-Alberni.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, yesterday Canadians have seen the bank rate rise for the sixth time since January just because of this government's mind-boggling desire to sustain the Canadian dollar.
With its monetary policy, it is only putting off the economic recovery even further. Unless we put an end to these repeated increases in the bank rate, there will be more bankruptcies, more lay-offs and more de-industrialization.
The Liberal Party of Canada, the Canadian pulp industry, the Conseil du Patronat du Quebec and the Canadian manufacturing industry, all denounce this government's irresponsible monetary policy.
I will tell the government that you don't need to destroy the economy to bolster the Canadian dollar. It should stop this nonsense immediately to put an end to this slump and put Canada back on track!

For months now, members in my caucus, particularly the members for Kootenay East, Edmonton East, Winnipeg Transcona and myself have been pursuing a renewal of coal contracts between Ontario Hydro and western Canadian coal producers in order to protect Canadian jobs.
Earlier this year, Shelley Wark-Martyn, the MPP for Port Arthur and minister of revenue and I convened a meeting in Thunder Bay between Ontario's minister of energy and members of a newly formed coalition. At that meeting, the minister of energy agreed to intervene with Ontario Hydro to see if a made-in-Canada solution could be found and he did.

March 13, 1992
Oral Questions
As we speak, Ontario Hydro is briefing harbour officials in Thunder Bay on the results of those negotiations and later today an announcement is to be made in Calgary.
I am confident that Ontario Hydro, the coal companies, the transporters and handlers have found a way to keep people working to reduce Hydro's costs and to send a clear signal that buying Canadian is a win-win situation. My congratulations to all concerned.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, there were five Alberta women who spearheaded the famous Persons case and the Government of Alberta was the first province to appoint a cabinet minister who was a woman in the Commonwealth. During this International Women's Week it is excellent news to receive the appointment of Madam Justice Catherine Anne Fraser as Chief Justice of Alberta and Chief Justice of the Court of Appeal for the Northwest Territories.
This appointment is not made because Madam Justice Fraser is a woman. She is a jurist of considerable merit, born of Ukrainian and Arab heritage in New Brunswick, a resident of Alberta for most of her life. She is a graduate of the University of Alberta and the University of London. She was admitted to the bar of Alberta in 1971, appointed a Queen's Counsel in 1983, appointed to the Court of Queen's Bench of Alberta in 1989 and to the Court of Appeal of Alberta in March 1991.
I am sure all members of the House join me in congratulating Madam Justice Catherine Anne Fraser, the new Chief Justice of Alberta.

Madam Speaker, I join the member for Laurier-Sainte-Marie who condemned yesterday the racist remarks by Mr. Mordecai Richler concerning the French Canadian people of Quebec.
As well I am shocked that the Minister of Multicultur-alism and Citizenship did not have the decency to respond to the question posed by the hon. member for Shefford-

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext: Order, order.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Bona-vista-Trinity-Conception.

Madam Speaker, yesterday in this House there was a debate on the Liberal motion that Canada should take immediate steps to extend functional jurisdiction for fishing to the nose and tail of the Grand Banks.
The purpose of the motion was to save an essential national industry and valued way of life for many rural Canadians, in particular Atlantic Canadians, from pillaging of Canada's transboundaiy fish stocks off the east coast.
There were 18 speakers from British Columbia to Newfoundland and much debate on both sides of the House. The government argued that it wanted to do more of the same, more diplomatic action. The opposition argued more of the same is not working. The motion unfortunately was defeated 90 to 51.
Also, yesterday, Canada's ambassador for fishing conservation ended yet another diplomatic shuttle across Europe without any sign whatsoever that the European Community will curb illegal overfishing off Newfoundland.
Clearly the government's gentle strategy is not working and a concerted escalation in effort is required to send a message to the world that Canada will stand by its people dependent on an industry that is being irretrievably crippled by foreigners.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport. The Canadian airline industry is going through some of the roughest times in its history.
In response to the minister's plans to privatize terminals 1 and 2 at Pearson airport, the president of the Air Transport Association of Canada said this, and I quote: "We want to minimize our costs to be able to compete
March 13, 1992

with U.S. airlines, but we never asked the minister to renovate the terminals and see no need for it."
Is the minister serious when he talks about making the Canadian airline industry more competitive while at the same time increasing its costs due to privatization?

Madam Speaker, I do not know where the hon. member got the idea that their costs will go up. We are well aware of the financial situation the airlines are in. We are working on it, through bilateral discussions with the U.S., among others things, in the hope of increasing traffic. But renovating terminals 1 and 2 is part of the plan to get ready to respond, when the time comes, to the increase in traffic expected for 1997-98.

Madam Speaker, the minister knows very well that the numbers come from the association and the airlines themselves.
Yesterday the minister agreed that the environmental assessment with respect to runway expansion at Pearson would not be available until August at the earliest. The minister also acknowledged that the problems some developers may face in responding within the 90-day time limit to the request for proposals may require him to extend the time limit if they have paid a deposit and shown that they were truly interested. This announcement reeks of unexplained, unwarranted haste.
Why does the minister not remove the foul odour of political favouritism and opportunism from the timing of the announcement of this project and do what Mr. Sinclair from the airline association suggested and simply wait until 1993 when we see how the airline industry shakes down?

Madam Speaker, Mr. Sinclair is a past assistant deputy minister in the Department of Transport. He is no longer occupying that position and does not make decisions for Transport Canada.
We have taken notice of his objection. We understand the objection of the airline industry because it is thinking about the bottom line of the next six months. We are
Oral Questions
thinking about the bottom line for the airline industry in five or six years' time.

Madam Speaker, what is not clear is who is making the decisions for Transport Canada on this issue.
What is happening here is that the minister has put forward an announcement that is unjustified by the numbers that he announced yesterday. It contradicts what he has in his own estimates. He has been unable to justify the timing, given the fact that the environmental assessment is still under way.
Why is the minister prepared to sacrifice a fair and open process in order to ensure that he has a photo opportunity for the Prime Minister standing with a shovel just in time for the next election?

Madam Speaker, I do not know if the member is referring to the same insinuation professed in this room yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition. If so, I would like to remind him that that particular gentleman is the father-in-law of one of his own colleagues from Willowdale.

Madam Speaker, the Minister of Transport predicts record growth to capacity within six years at Pearson airport. When asked how much revenue that will generate, the minister says: "I don't know". When asked how much it would cost the government to renovate terminals 1 and 2, the minister's response is: "I don't know".
Given that Pearson airport makes money, given that private developers are champing-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: There has been a long preamble. Will the hon. member come to a question?

My question is, Madam Speaker: Given that private developers are champing at the bit to get a lease arrangement with this government, what do they know that we do not know? What information has the minister given them that he will not provide for this House?

Madam Speaker, I am sure that you will not allow me the time necessary to tell the hon. member all that he does not know.

March 13, 1992
Oral Questions
On the other hand, we are proceeding on this because we think it is the necessary thing to do, to be able to keep Pearson airport as the main, well functioning airport in Canada. At the same time I remind the member that in a time where the economy is at a slow pace the creation of 3,200 jobs in the Toronto area is a very good gesture.

Madam Speaker, the stakeholders, the airlines and other levels of government are all saying the same thing. They agree that this is the wrong move at the wrong time.
Will the minister put the brakes on his request for proposals so that the transport committee can do what is in the best interest of the travelling public in this country?

Madam Speaker, this is very interesting because on Monday night in Toronto, at the request of the Ontario government, we had a meeting with the minister of transport of Ontario, the minister of the environment of Ontario and four or five mayors from the area.
A document was deposited with us at that time which says that three alternatives for the future ownership and operation of terminal 2 have been analysed. They are continued Transport Canada ownership, transfer to the private sector, or transfer to the SCOAA. Nowhere in this document is there any indication that the Ontario government is against the proposals.
Thble it.

I will certainly table it with very great pleasure. The only concern of the Ontario government was that it would like to form an LAA, on the board of which would sit the federal government, the provincial government and the municipal government. When the devolution of airport policy was adopted by this government, it said very clearly that it would not transfer airports to other levels of government.

Madam Speaker, since the budget came out last month, reports have shown our national income in decline, our interest rates rising, unemployment up yet further, and today comes more devastating news with a massive 2.4 per cent
decrease in manufacturing. This government is turning Canadian factories into ghost towns.
Will the government recognize that we are still in recession? Will it turn its budget policy in an opposite direction, start getting people back to work in this country and put the manufacturing industry ahead instead of back?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I will recognize without difficulty that the manufacturing industry is indeed going through a very worrisome period. I think everybody agrees with that.
We all know that the national demand is very weak. Foreign demand is very weak. That is why in our last budget we came forward with very precise measures, particularly to help the manufacturing industry, and I hope the hon. member realizes that.
What this situation commands us to do is to make the right decisions, to do everything we can as a government to maintain low interest rates because manufacturers need to be able to invest. They must be able to buy the machinery they need. These are measures we have taken in our budget.
As for interest rates, the hon. member knows that we also have to manage the debt. Every Thursday we put on auction a certain number of money bills or government certificates and people either buy or do not buy them. We are living in a very open market and the interest rates have to fluctuate according to that market.
As a government we do everything we can to try to keep them as low as possible and they are at a record low over the last-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: We must go on. The hon. member for Essex-Windsor.

Madam Speaker, in fact to give manufacturing incentives to invest at a time when the minister admits that there is not enough demand out there for manufacturing is like pushing on a string. It does not do anything.
Therefore I say to the minister: there is nothing that could hurt our manufacturing industry more than a North American trade deal. Yet the United States now says a deal could be just weeks away. On Monday the Prime Minister attacked our party for not wanting to help a Third World country like Mexico with this deal.
March 13, 1992

How can the government justify continuing in these negotiations for a free trade deal in North America now that GATT has attacked such a free trade deal as having far-reaching, adverse effects on poorer countries throughout the world?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I think the hon. gentleman will recognize this government has done everything it can to help lower the cost of Canadian products in our last budget through the GST reform.
We had this very stupid situation where one of the largest exporting countries in the world was the only one penalizing its own manufacturers. We have done our share and we continue to do it by making low cost capital available.
We have interest rates that have gone down, thanks to the good management of the government. What does he suggest we do? Should we borrow more money and send out the signal that we do not intend to keep our house in order by sending interest rates flying again?
We are not going to do that, nor are we going to raise taxes in order to spend money we do not have.

Madam Speaker, in fact this government for the past six weeks has seen interest rates pushed up in this country. For it to claim that interest rates are declining, thanks to its policy, is sheer nonsense. It just does not meet up with the facts at all.

Madam Speaker, I have a supplementary on transborder shopping in the United States, which has now increased by 30 per cent in Quebec.
Will this government finally realize that its economic strategy is worthless and merely provides an incentive for Quebecers and other Canadians to go and invest their money in the U.S. economy instead of in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the United States is also exposed to tremendous competitive pressures, which are increasing steadily. An extremely
Oral Questions
important point is that Canada, more than any other country in the world, depends on its external trade. Twenty-five per cent of what we build, produce or grow is exported, most of it to the United States.
Previously, our recourse, other than complying with U.S. demands, was very limited. However, thanks to the free trade agreement we now have a tribunal, and we have Canadians sitting on that tribunal, where we can bring these problems.
Two-way trade between Canada and the U.S. is worth hundreds of billions of dollars. When problems arise in certain sectors, we try to deal with them. We have expressed our views very firmly. We intend to defend our interests, and I am sure we will win our case.

Madam Speaker, my question is directed to the Acting Minister of Finance. Small businesses are genuine creators of durable jobs. However, they are now burdened with real interest rates almost six times as high as those charged their competitors in the United States.
How does the minister expect our small businesses to be competitive when they have this incredible burden to deal with?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I agree with the hon. member's analysis when he refers to the importance of small business. It is a sector with tremendous potential, which is indispensable to our economy.
Unfortunately the hon. member talks about interest rates as if the government could raise or lower them by merely pressing a button. They are higher than in the United States, and so we should lower them? I wish he would explain how a government could do that. And how the Liberal government, when it was in power, managed to let interest rates rise 22 per cent. Couldn't it press a button?
We cannot change the market, but by managing wisely, governments can inspire confidence. Since May 1990, interest rates have gone down 625 basis points. We are doing our share, but we cannot ask people to buy our bonds at 2 per cent, because they won't. Interest rates are set by the market.

March 13, 1992
Oral Questions

Madam Speaker, that kind of response, talking about nominal interest rates when the question is about real interest rates, does very little to further the economic debate in this country or the credibility of this House or the minister.
Our too high dollar and our too high real interest rates have led to a weakened economy. That weakened economy has led to even higher real interest rates, almost six times higher than the real interest rates in the United States, in order to support wrongly an over-valued Canadian dollar.
The government is caught in a vicious circle of its own making and those who are suffering from it are hundreds of thousands of unemployed Canadians across the land. This vicious circle must be broken. There is only one way for that to happen and that is to bring Canadian real interest rates into line with U.S. real interest rates.
The question is why will the government not do it? [Translation]

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I wish that someday the hon. member would explain how much leeway a government has to play around with interest rates this way.
The hon. member refers to interest rates and to our high dollar as one of the main reasons why we have this situation. In fact, I disagree with his analysis, because interest rates are much lower now, since we brought them down 625 basis points. The dollar is also going down, but we cannot intervene artificially in these areas.
The hon. member must know that the debt we inherited puts a tremendous obligation on us. We have to finance the debt year after year. People won't lend us the money we need at the rate we want but at the rate they want to charge us, because of international competition. We are not the only ones in the market. We try to get the best rate, like any good manager would. We managed to bring interest rates and the dollar down. We have done our share.

Madam Speaker, I have a question for the Acting Minister for International Trade. I just finished speaking to several well established wholesale lumber dealers in the city of Winnipeg. I think they speak for the same constituency right across Canada. They are being forced out of business by the dithering of this government on the softwood lumber issue. Not only must they pay 14.5 per cent additional costs on the lumber itself, but they now must pay additional costs on transport, loading, distribution, paper work resulting in a 25 per cent increase in costs. They have no choice but to move south.
I want to ask this question. It is the same question we have been asking every day this week. Why will the government not invoke the Employment Support Act which gives this government the authority to help companies affected by unfair trade practices by foreign countries? Why will it not try to help keep Canadian jobs here? What is it afraid of this time?

Madam Speaker, the issue my hon. friend refers to has to do with a preliminary ruling by the commerce department in the United States resulting from the termination of the memorandum of understanding.
My friend is quite correct. It is unfair and every measure is being taken to correct the issue. He is also right in saying the value added costs are captured in this new ruling. We have protested that to the United States and, of course, we are appealing the ruling at every step. As he knows, we are very much relying on article 19 of the free trade agreement which allows us access to an independent binding dispute mechanism which is of a judicial nature and there is no doubt that we will be vindicated in all questions of this issue.

Madam Speaker, the reality is that by the time the government gets around to all of this finagling under the free trade deal, all those companies will be located south of the border and we will have lost those jobs. They need help now.

Exactly.
March 13, 1992

I want to ask the Acting Prime Minister or perhaps the acting minister of trade, whomever, about another mess that we are getting ourselves into on the trade front.
We have this morning a statement by Carla Hills, the U.S. trade negotiator, that the North American free trade deal will be signed within a matter of weeks. At the same time, a GATT study released yesterday said to enact the deal will have adverse impact on world trade. I want to ask somebody in the government how we can get into this deal without Canadians even knowing what the conditions are, what the impact will be, how it will affect us and, by signing the deal, is this really Canada saying we are giving up on the international trading system?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: Madam Speaker, the hon. member knows better than that. He knows veiy well that Canada's main trading position is that we want to work with the GATT, the international trading operation. He also knows that we have benefited from the free trade agreement with the United States. He also knows that we will benefit from a free trade agreement with the whole of North America. That is exactly what the policy of this government is. We rely on trade for our economic growth. We intend to rely on trade and we intend to promote trade at every opportunity.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext: My question is for the Minister of Forestry. The news in our forest sector is just getting worse and worse by the day. Yesterday GATT issued a report denouncing U.S. trade policies. Now we have learned that the commerce department decision from last Friday on softwood lumber is also going to apply to the value added by service businesses in Canada to their United States exports. Can the minister tell this House specifically what measures the cabinet has met to discuss this week on this issue? What kind of remedies can he offer to these manufacturing businesses? Will he not agree that this attack goes beyond simply our softwood lumber exports? It is an attack on the manufacturing and semi-manufacturing industry in Canada.

Madam Speaker, we have already said that the decision is flawed in many different ways. It is peculiar in the sense that it would be the first time that a foreign jurisdiction has
Oral Questions
brought in a bonding requirement together with a preliminary decision on a countervail duty action. We have protested this measure at the highest levels. Certainly the fact that value-added products are captured with this duty is unacceptable. We have told the department of commerce that. We are appealing the decision. We have appealed the decision to GATT. A GATT panel has been established and will be ruling in June. As I said, we are very confident that at the end we will be vindicated.
Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley
Valley): Madam Speaker, when is the government going to realize that this is not a banana republic? We do not take orders from Washington, D.C. We run our forest policies our own way.
The Prime Minister was sabre rattling last weekend and in the last few days about how he is going to fight this decision. The cabinet was presumed to have met to review this matter. The minister did not tell the House anything new today in Question Period on this matter.
Can the minister tell this House what specific measures this government is going to take to protect our forest industry and to now protect our manufacturing industries that are suffering under this unwarranted attack from Washington, D.C.?

Madam Speaker, all is not doom and gloom. Fortunately, because of a very significant turnaround in the economy in the United States, prices for the kind of products my friend is talking about have increased by 30 per cent since the beginning of the year. That gives us small comfort, of course, in the sense that the United States has imposed a 15 per cent duty on our lumber exports.
We are not sitting by and letting this happen. Cabinet has met. We have protested the measure at the highest levels. We have appealed the measures to two tribunals. It is a preliminary hearing and one ought not to be spending the time of the House to alarm everyone.
My hon. friend comes from Prince George. He knows that a lumber company usually sets up and manufactures where the trees are. They just do not pack up tomorrow because they cannot take the trees with them. We will have to keep our cool and rely on the orders and rules

March 13, 1992
Oral Questions
that have been established under the free trade agreement and under GATT.
There is no doubt that we will be vindicated on both accounts.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
There is a lot of pubic concern about the possibility of the Yarmouth search and rescue helicopter being cancelled on March 31 of this year. Premier Cameron has said it was a top priority with him. I am wondering if the Acting Prime Minister knows whether the Prime Minister and Premier Cameron have had an opportunity to talk about such an important matter as it relates to search and rescue this week while at the conference?

Madam Speaker, on behalf of the minister of fisheries who is responsible for this portfolio, as my hon. friend knows, the department had established a base at Yarmouth and built a hangar at the facility. The $2 million a year contract is near its expiry date. The matter is under review. It has, of course, safety implications and the involvement of other departments. A decision will be made shortly.

Madam Speaker, I would just like to say the question was whether or not the premier had brought it up with the Prime Minister.
I hope the minister is telling the House that since we are in the middle of the month, the decision will be made immediately before the March 31 deadline when we have so much concern in the area about this. I do not see why a decision cannot be given today if it is so imminent.
Madam Speaker, the concerns in the area will of course influence the decision. It will be made very soon.

Madam Speaker, in the absence of the minister of fisheries, I direct my question to the Acting Prime Minister.
Last week the DFO Chief of Conservation and Protection said in relation to overfishing in the snow crab fishery that "the unfortunate part is we do not have the acceptable resources to monitor the fishing".
Therefore, will the minister commit the necessary resources to properly manage the fishery in Prince Edward Island?
Madam Speaker, knowing the minister of fisheries, his answer would obviously be in the affirmative. I will pass the hon. member's concern on to him.

Madam Speaker, my supplementary is for the same minister.
Fishermen in my riding want access to a larger snow crab fishery. Why will the minister not eliminate the artificial zone differences in the gulf and allow more Island fishermen to participate in the snow crab fishery?

Madam Speaker, one of the reasons there are no more licences for snow crab is because there are not enough snow crab for the number of fishermen who would like to get into that particular industry.
Nevertheless I will pass on the hon. member's question to the minister of fisheries.

Madam Speaker, my question today is for the Minister of Transport.
Yesterday there was a collision between a B.C. ferry and a bulk coal carrier out of Roberts Bank. This is the second collision by a B.C. ferry in the last five weeks. Many people are wondering what the problem is.
Can the minister assure us that there will be a careful examination and investigation of the causes of these collisions. Will they examine the structure of the ferries themselves? Is there some problem in the navigation equipment or is it in the operation?
Can he reassure the people in British Columbia, and those who are on the ferries, that everything will be done to prevent further collisions with injuries and loss of life, which fortunately did not occur on these two occasions?
March 13, 1992

Madam Speaker, we have been informed of these two incidents. We regret very much their occurrences. As the member just mentioned, we were very fortunate that there was no loss of life.
The Transportation Safety Board is presently investigating these two incidents. The reason and purpose for their investigation is precisely to accomplish what the member is seeking.

Madam Speaker, my question is also for the Minister of Transport.
On March 6 of this year, Bemie Wiens, the provincial minister of transport from Saskatchewan wrote a very pro-Churchill letter to the minister. In that letter he proposed a meeting of those parties that are very essential to the operation of the port, including the Canada Wheat Board, CN, the port itself, the province of Manitoba, along with the federal government.
Would the Minister of Transport be willing to support such a meeting and make the arrangements to have it?

Madam Speaker, as the hon. member knows, we have responded previously to a request for meetings from the various people involved in the port of Churchill. At the last meeting, we indicated that we were still examining the different components so that the port of Churchill could remain open if at all possible.
We have already indicated that next season the port will be operative. I can assure the member that as soon as we have the necessary information to move a step forward we will be happy to get this meeting organized.

Madam Speaker, the minister is correct, there have been meetings. I am very happy that he had a meeting with myself and other representatives in favour of the port of Churchill.
At that time, we asked for a moratorium on false statements coming from government officials and others with regard to the port of Churchill.
In light of the grains and oilseeds minister's remarks last week that a Brazilian ship struck an iceberg in the Hudson Bay area and welders had to be sent up there and the Brazilians were no longer going to use the port
Oral Questions
of Churchill, will the Minister of Transport inform the minister of grains and oilseeds that the Canadian Coast Guard said: "There was no such incident. The only incident of that type was in the Gulf of St. Lawrence."
Can we ask the minister of grains and oilseeds to stop making false statements on Churchill?

Madam Speaker, notice has been given of this question and I understand the Associate Minister of Employment and Immigration will respond.
The Minister of Employment and Immigration has given an exclusion order to an Eritrean refugee claimant Mrs. Mebrahtu and her three children aged 10, 6 and 4. They are to appear at the Rainbow Bridge at 9.30 a.m. Monday, March 16, bags in hand to be escorted to God knows where. A dreadful history causes this family to be husbandless and fatherless. Now Canadian government action renders them homeless and hopeless.
Surely this government can show some compassion and on humanitarian grounds reverse its decision and grant this single mother and three small children refugee status in Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would first like to thank the hon. member for Northumberland for giving me prior notice of the question she wanted to ask.
I am sure that she will understand that I cannot comment on a particular case here in the House of Commons. I know that our colleague is familiar with the refugee determination process, which is generous and allows Canada to protect those who need our help.
That being said, the decision on the question before us was made by independent decision-makers, who applied the Geneva Convention. Of course for every decision, humanitarian considerations and criteria are evaluated, as they were in the case referred to us in this House. But unfortunately, this request was deemed not to comply with the terms of refugee status under the Geneva Convention, I am sorry to say.

March 13, 1992
Oral Questions

Madam Speaker, the Mebrahtu family has been in this country for over a year. The children have settled into school and some normalcy. Our inefficient system of refugee assessment has increased the trauma of their present flight.
If the government refuses once again to show compassion to Mrs. Mebrahtu, what advice will it give to this homeless, hopeless woman as she and her three small children walk across the Rainbow Bridge on Monday morning?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it may be necessary to recall that the political situation in Ethiopia has improved and that of course decisions are always made in accordance with the Geneva Convention.
We should also remember in this House that the refugee determination system must not be considered a shortcut to immigrate to Canada. The decisions were made by independent officials and humanitarian considerations and criteria were also assessed.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Agriculture.
The minister knows that there is a new beef grading system about to be introduced, including an ungraded standard. However, there are no requirements for retailers to indicate grade standards on beef at the meat counter.
The consumer and the Canadian Cattlemen's Association want and Canadian consumers deserve to know what they are buying. Why will the government not require and enforce grading standards to be signed and product to be labelled in the meat counter?

Madam Speaker, I recognize the desire of the hon. member and the groups he has mentioned. Unfortunately, he would be better to put that question to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs who has that responsibility.

Madam Speaker, press reports today indicate that the government has finally completed a study on U.S. subsidies, many of them hidden, to American agriculture producers. In only seven states they amount to $12.2 billion. It is interesting that the government has negotiated the FTA during the last six years and is now negotiating at the GATT.
I want to ask the Minister of Agriculture why the government has failed to have this critical information available on U.S. subsidies to agriculture producers for the GATT negotiations until the 11th hour. It was almost too late. Many thousands of fanners are depending on these negotiations for their very livelihood. Why has the government failed to have this information available for these critical negotiations.

Madam Speaker, the hon. member is mistaken that the government or the industry was not aware of the subsidies that had been identified in the report. The government was certainly aware of the federal U.S. subsidies identified in that report. The government was aware of some of the state subsidies in those seven states. The report identified additional subsidies or programs. I think it would be unfair to call all of them subsidies, but some are programs that assist agriculture in those seven states, some of which were not known to the government at that time. Much more work would have to be done to identify whether those programs are subsidies or legitimate programs, such as we use in Canada, to support agriculture.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Acting Minister of Finance. Last December 17 the minister responsible for CMHC in a press release promised $6.1 million for the co-op housing program. His credibility certainly is ruined by the recent budget.
Is the minister aware that budget cuts which arbitrarily eliminated co-op housing mean that well over 6,000 families on waiting lists in Vancouver now have no hope of housing? What does he say to city councils and housing groups right across Canada that are outraged at this betrayal?
March 13, 1992

He doesn't care.

speakeroldname: Mr. Dave Worthy (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I will give the benefit of the doubt and assume that the member's true interests are really those people in need, the people that we are targeting our housing programs for.
There are over 650,000 people in need in the country who receive housing assistance. For the next five years we have allocated $2 million a year for social housing. This totals $10 million. That is not shabby treatment, considering we are in a serious restraint mode.
If your interests are in an organization, that is one thing. Our interest is in servicing the needs of the people who have targeted needs.

Madam Speaker, that statement is outrageous. It shows that this acting minister knows nothing about co-op housing and the needs of people who need housing. I am ashamed of him.
In Vancouver, I would like to tell this member, the homelessness, the high rents and a whole influx of newcomers creates an excessive demand for affordable housing. I would like to say that part of the former Expo lands were promised for co-op and social housing creating in a mixed community, the best way to develop housing for those in need.
Will the minister explain how this much needed affordable housing can be built on Expo lands in Vancouver now that federal assistance has been wiped out for housing?

speakeroldname: Mr. Dave Worthy (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, federal assistance has not been wiped out. We continue to provide support for the 14,800 units of co-op housing now as well as the people who are currently living in 650,000 units of social housing.
We will be providing 28,000 new social housing units this year. It is our intention to help those in need, those who are targeted with a true need, not every program that wants housing.

Madam Speaker, I want to follow up a question asked the Acting Prime Minister by the member for Winnipeg South Centre. Softwoods are under siege right now by the Americans and we are losing jobs daily. A lot of those jobs are going south.
Will the Acting Prime Minister not act now and use the authority that he has under the Employment Support Act to protect these jobs? It is easier to keep them than to get them back after they have gone away.

Madam Speaker, as I said in a response to an earlier question, the industry of which my hon. friend speaks-he is probably not as familiar with it as I would be-usually works around the resource. You do not build a lumber mill or a manufacturing plant that depends on trees some place where there are not any trees. Therefore, the fear of everybody packing up to move to the United States is not well founded.
I told his hon. friend that we are dealing with this issue at the highest level; that we are dealing with a preliminary decision and that we are dealing with a process that will finish in July. The drastic measures that he is suggesting simply do not work in this particular situation.

Madam Speaker, you do not have to be an expert to know the headlines, "Jobs axed over U.S. duty", "Jobs heading south". We cannot wait for this process to begin next summer.
My supplementary question is the following. On Wednesday, when asked about the Honda dispute, the trade minister said: "Chapter 19 of the FTA is a binding dispute mechanism that is the final stage".
In the absence of the trade minister, may I ask the Acting Prime Minister to tell our trade minister two things. First of all, to read the free trade agreement and second, to ask him to recognize that chapter 19 does not deal with the Honda dispute. The minister may wish it would, but it does not under the deal that was cut with the Americans.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext: The hon. member knows very well that Canada is doing everything it possibly can with respect to this Honda dispute. Every minister, every department of government, is making its opposition known to every position in the United States. We are quite convinced that on the Honda dispute, we are in the right and we will win. The Americans may not like that language of win/lose, but we use it because we are confident we will win this dispute.

Madam Speaker, I appreciate your indulgence.
Yesterday we spoke in the House on the motion to extend functional jurisdiction for fishing to the nose and tail of the Grand Banks. The government's response essentially was: "We will continue to do more of the same with diplomatic action".
Madam Speaker, in response to this diplomatic action, I notice in the news this morning there was an indication that Mr. Randolph Gherson, who is Canada's ambassador for fisheries conservation, ended a diplomatic shuttle across Europe yesterday as we were in this House talking with few signs that the European Community will do anything to curb their overfishing. In particular, British and Danish officials said they needed more time. The Spanish and the Portuguese said that they were not ready to accept Canada's position.
Can I ask the Secretary of State for External Affairs what she now plans to do to stand by a people who are dependent on an industry that has been wounded and irretrievably crippled by foreigners?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as I pointed out yesterday in the debate in the House, one of the things that has happened as a result of this trip is that the scientific data which we have presented quite openly and with all the facts is fairly long and fairly complex.
When the Portuguese and the Spanish governments were presented with the data, even though the initial response was very unwelcoming, they were quite shaken by what they saw, but they do want time to examine it.
I consider this a positive development. I do not know how long it will take them to examine it. I will be discussing this with the European Commission again within the next two weeks. The fact that they have the data and are looking at it and taking it seriously is exactly what we want them to do right now. We want them to move on it quickly.

Madam Speaker, after I asked my second question in the House of the Minister of Transport, there was no answer.
I recognize that there is no requirement for the minister to answer a question, however, I would like permission of the House, if the minister is not willing to do it, to table the document from the Canadian Coast Guard which indicates that there was no Brazilian ship which encountered an iceberg in 1989, 1990, 1991. Madam Speaker, I have the honour to present to the House today a petition signed by residents of my riding, Ottawa Centre, and surrounding areas in the Ottawa region.
These people ask Parliament to urge the government to correct the injustice caused by high gasoline prices in the Ottawa-Carleton region.

Madam Speaker, I have the pleasure of presenting a petition signed by some 28 people from my constituency and also from London, who are in support of the parents of Nina de Villiers in deploring the apparent increase in crimes of violence, and calling for appropriate amendments to the Criminal Code of Canada, the Bail Reform Act and the Parole Act.

Madam Speaker, I have the honour to present a petition signed by over 500 constituents of mine. These were gathered by Diane Lea of Elliot Lake and concern the Nina de Villiers case.
This petition calls on the government to take action to improve the bail and the other parole laws in this country, including sentencing and possession of firearms laws to ensure that we protect our society so that needless violent crimes like the murder of Nina de Villiers last summer will cease in this country and we will have a more safe and secure society.

Madam Speaker, it is an honour to present under Standing Order 36 a petition containing over 1,000 names from many communities on the lower mainland. The petitioners are concerned about the inequality of taxation with regard to the family.
They are asking that Parliament amend the Income Ihx Act so that child related benefits and deductions for child care are fair and equitable to all family structures based on financial need and irrespective of child care choice. I think they recognize that some of this has already been done but they are looking for further changes as well.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext: Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I have here petitions signed by many people in my riding concerning the murder of Nina de Villiers on August 9, 1991. This murder brought out serious deficiencies in the criminal justice system. For these reasons, the petitioners ask Parliament to recognize that violent crimes against persons are serious and abhorred by society and to amend the Criminal Code of Canada, the Bail Reform Act of 1972 and the Parole Act accordingly.

Madam Speaker, it is my privilege to stand here with a petition from residents of Canada who wish to present a grievance to this House with the hope that the government will be able to provide some remedial action. They say: "Whereas, as Canadians we are fortunate to live in a multicultural society and we are committed to traditional humanitarian principles and abhor human rights violations".
They are asking that Canadians join in commemoration this Sabbath of remembrance for our oppressed people, the Jews, particularly the 4,500 living in Syria, and who are denied all civil liberties. They have no voting rights. They cannot be candidates in elections. They are banned from government employment and, whereas Amnesty International has reported that there are Syrian Jews who have been imprisoned without
March 13, 1992

informing families and without defence or trial and that these people are beaten, tortured and sometimes murdered, Syrian Jews being denied the right to emigrate-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I do apologize for interrupting but the hon. member knows that no matter how good the cause is, presenting a petition should not turn into a speech. Please conclude.

Madam Speaker, I was reading what the petitioners had to say. I will terminate it there. I thank you for your guidance but these petitioners pray that on Shabbat Zachor that Parliament will call upon Syria to lift all these repressive restrictions and permit members of the Jewish community to emigrate freely in accordance with the United Nations' own human bill of rights, Article 13, to which Syria is a signatory.

Madam Speaker, I have the honour to present a petition on behalf of residents of the city of Winnipeg. This petition was collected through the work of Doug Martindale, one of the MLAs in the city. It is with regard to the Canada Post Corporation decision to close Empire Drugs at 801 Selkirk Avenue. This drugstore has provided convenient hours for residents, many of whom are of ethnic background, many of whom are seniors who do not speak English.
They have provided an excellent service to the people in that region. The petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to do all within its mandate to gain reconsideration of the decision of Canada Post Corporation to discontinue postal services at this location.

Madam Speaker, I would like to present two petitions on two issues.
The first petition is on behalf of many petitioners who humbly pray and call upon Parliament to recognize housing as a shared provincial-federal responsibility, to support the federal non-profit Co-operative Housing Program and to maintain the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation. They mainly live in my constituency on Burrows Avenue, Tyndall and Dickens Drive. They are concerned that the current constitutional proposals could transfer jurisdiction over housing to the provinces without compensation, including the responsibility for non-profit co-op housing which is a program that provides thousands of Canadian families with quality afford-
Routine Proceedings
able shelter, and that the provinces would be unable to wholly support this program.

Madam Speaker, the second petition relates to the recent government immigration directive.
The petitioners call upon Parliament to rescind this new directive, acknowledge the contribution of past, present and future foreign domestic workers to Canada's social and economic well-being, restore our Canadian values of tolerance and humanitarianism and preserve Canada's international esteem.
The petitioners are concerned that the new directive is insensitive to the needs of Canadian employers, callously disregards the needs of the women of the world and contradicts a fundamental principle of Canada's longstanding, non-discriminatory immigration policy.

Madam Speaker, I am honoured to be able to present a petition from the people of Manitoba, many of whom are constituents, for the people of the north and east of Sri Lanka who live in fear and apprehension without any hope of peace because of an economic blockade placed by the Government of Sri Lanka. This blockade has led to severe shortages of food, medicine and fuel and only a fraction of the relief assistance is going to the affected population. The current policy of the Government of Sri Lanka is to find a military solution.
The petitioners ask the government to intervene to stop the flagrant violations of human rights and to ensure basic essentials such as food and medicine and fuel.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am delighted with my colleague opposite. I thought he said "more". He wants to give me more time and I would be delighted to take it.
