As we were finishing the morning, I was saying that the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, the negotiations with Mexico and the United States and the GATT negotiations in Geneva are all part of a strategy aimed at increasing our participation in global markets and making us more competitive and thus more prosperous.
This trade component of the government's program is matched by complementarity in domestic initiatives. Our efforts to reduce the deficit, to promote price stability, to lessen the regulatory burden, to privatize Crown corporations, to encourage retraining, to upgrade skills, to modernize industry and to increase value added components in the economy, all of these seek to make Canada a more rewarding place in which to invest. It is investment by private entrepreneurs, Canadian and foreign, that will create the jobs of the future; good jobs, paying jobs, jobs with a future. From the fur trade to free trade, trade has been the vocation of Canada.
Today, Canadians enjoy an unprecedented level of prosperity as a result of our historically strong trade performance. Our success in buying and selling on the world market has made us a major contributor to and beneficiary of the global economy. Exports have been one of the main engines of growth and job creation in the Canadian economy and imports have greatly enriched the quality of our lives.
Many of the products of our lakes, forests, fields and mines were developed for export to the markets of Europe, Asia and the United States. Canada's evolution from colony to nation was indelibly shaped by our experience as world traders.
The approach that worked then is not necessarily the approach that will work today. Just as industries need to adapt, so do governments. We must be informed by our past success, but not be shackled by it. The trading world of the sixties and the seventies, and it appears clear that the proposer of this resolution wants us to go back to those days, is not the trading world of today. Today we face, whether one likes it or not, a globalized trading economy.
Trade was the engine of growth. Now it is investment and technology. Canada can benefit from these new circumstances. We do not have to be afraid of them. We have many strengths. We are the seventh largest economy in the OECD. It was these changing economic circumstances which disposed us to take the road to free

March 13, 1992
Supply
trade at the beginning of our mandate. These circumstances have, if anything, become more compelling.
In 1985 we were seeing only the early signs of the phenomenon we dub now as globalization. Today the signs are unmistakable. We, like the Americans and the Japanese and indeed all other trading nations, are a part of that global economy. We cannot lift the drawbridge and ignore it. Our standard of living now depends on joining the global economy and winning.
There are direct challenges to Canada which can be summed up in a simple phrase. By the end of the decade, we must transform ourselves from a trading nation into a nation of traders. The FTA, the GATT negotiations, the trilateral negotiations, our prosperity initiative, the February budget, the learning initiatives, are all part of reaching that objective. No one doubts that we are a trading nation, but I think that we are not yet a nation of traders and surely that is where we have to head. Our trading culture remains yet too shallow. We still export too limited a range of products to too few markets. Not enough Canadians accept that international business is the key to future growth.
It is clear again that the proposers of this resolution simply do not accept that Canada must compete on a world scale, that every Canadian must have a stake in global competition and we will not achieve that by hiding from the world. We will not achieve that by withdrawing from the NAFTA negotiations. We will not achieve that by withdrawing from the free trade agreement. We will certainly not achieve it if we do not adapt. Trade is where our domestic economy meets the international economy and a successful export performance is a pretty good indication that we are able to be competitive at home and that the domestic economy is working.
Adjusting, becoming more competitive, is where the future lies. Our past record has been reasonable, but we have to do better. We have to improve our productivity. We have to keep prices stable. We have to accept and join with enthusiastically the ability to compete at home and abroad. We have to invest in the future and provide an economic climate for both Canadian and foreign investors alike.
That is why the government negotiated free trade with the United States. That is why we are negotiating a free trade agreement with the United States and Mexico. That is why we want to conclude a successful agreement at the NTM. That is why we want to reduce the deficit. That is why we want to keep inflation low. We want to reduce the heavy hand of government in the economy unlike the members opposite and the proposers of this resolution.
We believe if we do that the result will be a growing-stronger outward-looking economy that all Canadians can share in. I want to share in such an economy and I want to be part of the fight that takes us there and I want my children to reap the benefits.

Madam Speaker, I listened attentively to the speaker and there are a lot of things he said that we agree with on this side of the House.
We have always agreed to freer trade, more liberalized trade. In fact, 80 per cent of our trade in this country was free before we had this free trade agreement.
I want to refer him specifically to chapter 16 of the free trade agreement under article 1603 under performance requirements where it says:
1. Neither Party shall impose on an investor of the other Party, as a term or condition of permitting an investment in its territory, or in connection with the regulation of the conduct or operation of a business enterprise located in its territory, a requirement to:
a)	export a given level or percentage of goods and services;
b)	substitute goods or services from the territory of such Party for imported goods or services; and
c)	purchase of goods or services used by the investor in the territoiy of such Party or from suppliers located in such territory or accord a preference to goods or services produced in such a territory; or
d)	achieve a given level or percentage of domestic content.
Would the minister not agree that American multinational corporations with branch offices in Canada that have been doing an awful lot of research and development, a lot of manufacturing, have now because of the deep recession in the United States basically taken article 1603 of the free trade agreement and used it as an instrument for retrenching, practically eliminating R and D and manufacturing? Essentially there is no investment
March 13, 1992

requirement or there is no enticement for investment requirement in this country.
Under this law we have basically said to the head offices: "You can do what you want in this country". That, in my humble opinion, has led to one of the reasons that so many American corporations have pulled back and why we have so many people out of work, especially in central Ontario.

Madam Speaker, this is somewhat typical of some of our colleagues in the House who really do not believe in free trade. They want to hedge things around because presumably they do not believe Canada competes either in terms of R and D tax credits or other matters.
It is very clear. I can give you all kinds of illustrations of companies that have not pulled back one bit and certainly not pulled back in Canada more than they have in the United States. I could talk about Pratt & Whitney, I could talk about IBM. They may be retrenching but they are not retrenching in Canada any more than they are in the United States.
People tend always when they talk about these issues to talk about the automobile industry. They focus on the automobile industry. That is an industry I know very well indeed, and that industry strangely enough is doing a little more now than it was some time ago. I think it is a disgrace in terms of the automotive industry research and development in this country. I have been saying so for 40 years and I will continue to say so. That does not mean it is doing less; in fact, it is doing a little more, infinitesimally more on an infinitesimally small base.
I think that blaming all the ills of this current recession on the free trade agreement has become a habit and not reality.

Madam Speaker, I want to compliment the Minister for Science on his comments and, indeed, on his commitment here today, because as we discuss this important issue of trade, it is indeed crucial, as the hon. minister has mentioned, that Canadians become traders.
I want to just bring up a couple of examples and ask the minister about one in particular. There are three examples I want to mention.
Supply
Last week I visited a company in London, Ontario. The company is called Trojan Technologies. It specializes in ultraviolet disinfection, research, product development, design systems, marketing, manufacturing and service. What this company does is it actually has these ultraviolet rays that take the bacteria out of waste water.
That company has placed some 70 representatives in the United States and Canada to promote their technology. Up to 1991, it has sold or had in operation 500 municipal waste water ultraviolet disinfection systems in the United States, Canada, New Zealand and Australia.
Officials told me that the company's success has been directly related to the free trade agreement.
In Scarborough, CDA Industries has created 90 additional jobs because of the free trade agreement. This company is the largest design company in Canada designing display products. It designs in paper, wood, plastic, metal. A great success story.
The other company I would like to mention and have the minister comment on is a company that he himself visited in Scarborough, called Webcom Limited. It is of particular interest to me from the environmental point of view because it has a unique competitive edge.
That company's business is printing books, directories and catalogues, and two of the things it has done to make itself competitive is that it has used vegetable-based inks, which we certainly endorse, and it uses recycled paper. I understand it has about 200 employees in Canada right now, and because of the free trade agreement it has increased its sales and increased the number of employees.
I would like the minister to give us some indication of what he found when he visited Webcom in Scarborough.

Madam Speaker, what I found was a very aggressive company using the best of technologies. It has looked at technologies around the world in terms of binding periodicals and journals. It has used that technology, modified it some, and it is now one of the leading companies in North America in this new binding process.

March 13, 1992

Supply
I also found that the company was very aggressive in terms of moving into the United States, and that the United States market was now making up a substantial portion of all of its production.
The company was extraordinarily pleased with the free trade agreement and the access that it gave to that market.
When talking to company officials, I said: "Obviously we have made the right move as far as your company is concerned. Is there anything else that we could do that would help you in terms of capitalizing on the technology and the sales approach that you have?"
They said that yes, they would like a little different arrangement in terms of capital cost allowance for equipment because they intended to stay number one in that business.
I have no doubt that when they saw the budget of a few weeks ago they were very pleased indeed that we had modified the capital cost allowance and the reduction in tax.
That is exactly what we have been trying to do and what I have been trying to emphasize in my speech today.
When my colleague the Minister of State for Environment took me to Webcom, she knew that I was going to see technology in action, free trade in action, listen to people in action.
That is exactly what this government is about. We believe if we do not do that, we will not be competitive. Our position is that we want to be competitive. That is why we have the free trade agreement. We are going to continue to push for freer trade anywhere in the world. We believe that Canadians can win.
Mir. Jim Peterson (Willowdale): Madam Speaker, the motion we face in this House today, put forward by the NDP is naive and simplistic at best. Its members would have us walk from the North American free trade agreement table. They would have us have no representation there, no observers, no possibility for protecting whatever best interests of Canada might lie at that table.
We all recognize that the benefits for Canada in entering into a free trade agreement with the Mexicans may not be very great, but at least we have to be there at
the table to protect our interests. Such naivety. They would ask us to immediately cancel the free trade agreement.
The member for Winnipeg Transcona who proposed this, said: "We recognize there is going to be harm to Canadians. We recognize there is going to be harm but we choose to do that. We choose to get rid of the free trade agreement immediately".
But did he lay figures before this House showing what additional jobs we might lose if we were to immediately cancel out of the free trade agreement? Did he lay a study before us of the industries that would be further
affected?
I do not stand here trying to make a brief for the government that this free trade agreement is working at all to our interests. I am going to come to some very specific details to show where it is adversely affecting certain jobs in Canada.
But to the NDP members who want to abrogate it, give us their studies to show that we will achieve greater benefits by cancelling now. That is an irresponsible approach. Until they are prepared to come forth with those studies we cannot give any credence to the blind faith without figures that they can make things better their way.
The other thing that bothers me about the approach of the socialist party members in this House is that they are tending to be totally simplistic in laying all of the blame for our economic perils today on free trade. We know that is not the case.
The Tories gave us a free trade deal which we asked them not to sign, which we opposed, not because it was free trade but because it was not giving us the level playing field we need.
Also, having given us free trade this government then instituted a multiplicity of other policies which have helped to drive jobs out of Canada.
The dollar went up about 25 per cent from when free trade was first postulated. This of course put a 25 per cent burden on our exporters which was a ball and chain and a far worse penalty than any of the American tariffs that the FTA removed.
They gave us interest rates which have been consistently significantly higher than American rates. Today Canadian rates are double those in the U.S.
March 13, 1992

There is another thing the NDP does not point out to us and is certainly part of the conclusion of our task force on deindustrialization and economic renewal. This is the testimony of businesses right across the province. Not only the high dollar, high interest and high tax policies of this Tory government but what was really throwing a cloud on the investment future of Ontario was the impending labour legislation proposed by the NDP government. Looking at the labour legislation, one witness said that none of the particular measures were particularly bad on their own but taken as a whole, business did not compete in Ontario with other Canadian jurisdictions or with the more likely aspect that they would move to the United States.
Therefore, as much as we want workers to have rights, opportunities and fairness, these things must all be looked at within the context of international competition and what we have to do as Canadians to create jobs.
Let us look at some of the other policies of this Tory government that are causing very severe difficulties. Cross-border shopping is symptomatic of giving us free trade and not having a level playing field for Canadians. Our task force discovered the biggest cause of crossborder shopping which is bleeding Canada out of anywhere from about $3 billion to $5 billion a year and is decimating border communities. From the Sarnia area and right into Montreal, cross-border shopping is just decimating many communities in Canada. Why? It is cheaper in many cases to shop in the United States because we have different fiscal regimes.
The biggest cause of cross-border shopping is the high cost in Canada of gasoline and diesel fuel. That is the single biggest draw. Did the government deal with that issue when it brought out measures three weeks ago? It did not even touch it. It did not deal with the root cause.
What did the government do instead? It said: "We will enter into a collection regime with the provinces. We will collect for them the PST, the province sales taxes, if they will buy into our scheme for the GST". In other words, if they will start taxing more things for the provincial revenue than they are presently taxing and if they will increase their taxes to the provinces then the government will collect. It is doing that in the midst of the triple dip recession in Canada. The provinces have not bit. They will not be blackmailed or cajoled into doing this.
Supply
What is another measure the government took to try to correct this cross-border shopping? It said: "What we will do, because cigarettes are smuggled into Canada from the United States, is impose a duty on cigarettes that leave Canada for the United States", a prepayment of the GST.
It might help some of the smuggling problem, but it is really driving jobs to the United States. Now the tobacco companies are finding that they cannot compete and their jobs are going to the United States. Canadians are not going to pay for the increased cost of Canadian cigarettes. They will be buying American cigarettes which do not have this tax imposed on them.
While it might have been a good effort to deal with some of the problems, it was naive. It was not worked out. It is not going to work. It is not going to solve the problem. It is just going to drive more jobs south of the border.
What else did the government do in terms of our mail order industry which was suffering greatly and losing jobs hand over fist vis-a-vis the Americans? The Americans imposed about a $10 Canadian charge on any Canadian mail order goods going into the United States. However, Canada did not impose this on the American goods coming into Canada.
What does our government do? It says: "We will go half way. We will retaliate but we will not charge American mail order companies $10. We will charge them only $5". How stupid. Why did the government not do the same things that the Americans did to us to give our mail order industry at least a level playing field?
I do not know where this government's head is. I do not know who it is listening to. It is obviously not consulting with the industry. Any child could tell the government: "Hey, that is not a level playing field you are creating. Don't pretend you have fixed it when you have not".
Another area where we have seen a great loss of jobs, at least 1,700, is in Canada's printing industry. Maybe the concept of free trade was there and over five years we would get rid of all the duties and tariffs. The printing industry was not against this necessarily, but since free trade it has 1,700 jobs.

March 13, 1992
Supply
Why? Because we do not have a level playing field and the government did not ensure that we did. It was not just tariffs. Now American authorities are imposing a multiplicity of specifications so that Canadian printers must put labels in various spots and big highlighting. Not only do they have a multiplicity of regulations, but they are differently enforced at different border crossings. We have an administration system which is not giving us that playing field.
Another thing that was totally naive was that the Americans know we have to put on our printed goods a big "Made in Canada" and are going to be turned away from it. Why? It is not because of the Canadian quality, but because they have had in place in the United States for many, many years a buy American program, which is a type of nationalism and chauvinism to help their own workers, which we have called for in Canada, but which this government has not brought forward.
In concept freer trade; in reality it just is not there because we do not have a level playing field. Naivety, ignorance, stupidity. The theoiy is right, but they did not do their homework. This is why we continue to lose jobs in this area.
Another area is manufacturing. In the whole manufacturing sector in Canada since the free trade came in we have lost 345,000 or 16 per cent of our manufacturing jobs.
How can we sustain a vibrant economy when we lose our best paying jobs? Is this all because of free trade? Don't get me wrong; the NDP would probably say it is but it is a multiplicity of issues. If we are given free trade, a higher dollar, higher interest, higher taxes, and impending labour legislation from a socialist government in Ontario, the jobs are not going to stay in Canada.
What did the government do to tiy to ensure that we had a level playing field before we went into it? Why did it tip the playing field against Canada with its higher interest rates? This is one of the tragedies. We have not bottomed out of this recession. The last reports showed that unemployment is going up. We went from 10.4 per cent last month to 10.6 per cent unemployment. Nowhere was this worse than in manufacturing, the key to the industrial heartland of Ontario and Canada. We lost
22,000	more manufacturing jobs in January.
Let us look at the auto industry. The Minister for Science said it was the fault of the auto industry that we are losing jobs, that it did not do enough R and D in Canada. If the government told that industry to do more R and D in Canada and made it a condition of being in Canada, it would do it. Otherwise it will do its R and D in Detroit and Tokyo. These other countries are not naive.
Let us look at our automotive industry and what has happened to it since free trade. We have lost 27,213 jobs or 21 per cent of our auto parts and assembly jobs in Canada in the three years since free trade. The government tells us that jobs are also being lost in the United States. Yes they are. The Americans have lost 9 per cent of their auto jobs in the past three years. We are losing jobs at two and one-third times the U.S. rate. Is that just because of free trade? No, it is a whole ball of wax that this government has given us in terms of its policy.
I would like to put before this House today some specific amendments to our trading relationships that I think could address the auto sector. First, under the free trade agreement we have a 50 per cent North American content rule. If we have 50 per cent North American content as defined, we will have duty free trade between Canada and the United States. I am going to propose that this is not enough. Canadian content will have to be increased, perhaps to the level of 60 or 75 per cent. In order to grant that privilege of free trade to others they will have to create a substantial number of jobs and give us significant North American content.
Second, under the free trade agreement we have wiped out the auto pact. The auto pact is very simple. It had a safeguard protection for Canadian jobs. It said: "If you want to produce a car outside Canada and bring it into Canada duty free, you have to produce one car in Canada or its equivalent". That was fair. That was from the auto pact. That was wiped out by the free trade agreement.
Under the free trade agreement, by the year 1998 when all duties are eliminated, the big three could pull every plant out of Canada. They would not have to buy
March 13, 1992

one Canadian part. They could ship their cars duty free into Canada without creating one single job here.
Is that what we want to see? We are seeing the evolution of that right now when we are losing auto jobs at two and one-third times the U.S. rate. We have to go back to some type of Canadian content.
I am advocating Canadian content of perhaps even 100 per cent. We are going to need a Canadian content that restores to us what the auto pact gave us. Any Canadian content rule that does not say: "You have to produce one car in Canada or its equivalent for every car you bring in duty free" is not giving us as Canadians our fair share of the job market.
People are going to say: "This is protectionism". Of course it is protectionism. Free trade is not what our competitors are doing. In the European Community they are debating today whether foreign producers will have 15 per cent or 17 per cent of the European Community's auto market by the year 2000. Will they let it get up that high? In Canada we are at 37 per cent foreign penetration right now. In return for that 37 per cent of our auto market those people are producing only 3 per cent of our jobs.
Is Japan a free trader? What is the percentage of its market occupied by foreign or non-Japanese producers? It is 3 per cent. It is 3 per cent in Japan, 15 to 17 per cent within eight years in the European Community, and in Canada today it is 37 per cent and rising. They are not free traders. Why should we be the only Boy Scouts on the block?
We need a dispute settlement mechanism that works. We do not have one today. Let us look at the Honda dispute. The engines are made in the United States for Honda and the United States says: "Hey, there is not enough North American content". The rules for specific determination of North American content under the FTA were not worked out at the table. They were so happy to get any deal they walked before they did the details. They did not even do the subsidies.
We are seeing what is happening now. We do not have a definition of content we can agree on. So what happens? The American customs authorities can slap a duty on us. Fine, but do we have an objective means of settling this dispute under the vaunted free trade settlement dispute mechanism? Is there a way to do it fairly and in accordance with the principles of law? No.
Supply
The only right we have is under chapter 18 of the free trade agreement that says we must consult with them. We are consulting right now. If we cannot agree after we have consulted then we can strike a panel to arbitrate it, but that panel's decision cannot be binding on the United States unless the United States says it will be binding. How stupid. Why would the United States agree that the decision should be binding when its customs officials and its administration have already decided in favour of the United States. That is the position we are in and do not pretend that free trade agreement gives us one right we did not have before in terms of this Honda dispute. What is such a shame is that we have production in Canada to the North American market. The Honda syndrome can be applied to every other Canadian producer for the North American market and for the U.S. market. The chill that it will put on further exports from Canada and on further investment in Canada producing for the U.S. market is enormous. If you were going to make the decision as a North American corporation to establish in Canada or in the United States, why would you choose Canada, when because of the Honda type decision and the inadequacies of the free trade agreement, nine-tenths of your market, i.e., the United States, can be shut off?
I am coming quickly to a conclusion. There is so much that is wrong with this agreement, the free trade agreement, because it was not thought out. It does not give Canada a level playing field. It has not given our producers and our jobs a fair chance. I have touched on just perhaps three of the industries in which this has not been the case.
Let us renegotiate. Let us get a fair deal for Canadians.

Madam Speaker, when the hon. member started speaking and agreed that a trade agreement, the North American free trade agreement, was a good idea, I thought that we might hear a sensible speech today. But I was wondering, when he got into the mathematics of the Canadian dollar, how he figured it. It was new math to me. In any event, the Canadian dollar was trading at about 84 cents to the American dollar in December 1988, and now it is 83.5 cents to the American dollar. I just wondered what kind of new math that was, where he said the Canadian

March 13, 1992
Supply
dollar lost 25 per cent of its value against the American dollar.
Then he went on from there into the auto pact. You know, when he said we produce two cars for every one we consume here, as far as the Americans are concerned, he really lost me. Then when we had the General Motors matter, where they are closing plants in the United States-and, sure, they closed a plant in Canada, but they closed a lot more plants in the United States-I got confused.
Then he went on even further and got into horrible matters concerning the establishment of plants and businesses in Canada. I looked at the exports of Canadian goods into the United States, and in 1988 there was $102.6 billion and then it was $107 billion in 1991. The difference between our favourable balance continued to rise. We find now that our favourable balance is $15.1 billion, when it was only $14 billion in 1988. This is a bad year because our trade on both sides has dropped.
I wonder just where he is getting off. I mean, he must have some sort of idea that we are not capable of running a country. I think he must be reading either the new dinosaurs' material or Mr. Hurtig's material, or doing his research somewhere that has no relevance to what is in fact taking place.
We have a problem in Ontario, and he is right. It was his brother who was premier of a province that spent and increased taxes, and borrowed money in foreign markets and increased the value of the Canadian dollar until he was defeated and his province taken over by the real big spenders, the New Democrats. It was his brother's government that created a growth in the province of Ontario that was unsustainable. That is really why the province of Ontario is suffering and suffering very badly today in this recession, far worse than other places in the world. But let him know there is a world recession, and it is worse in Ontario because of the leadership offered by the government headed by his brother and by the current premier of Ontario, who seems to have no sense at all.

Mr. Speaker, I have never had to defend my brother because he has always been superbly capable of doing it himself.
One has to wonder where the Prime Minister finds his judgment on so many matters that are of such vital importance to the future of Canada. Needless to say, I am very proud of my brother and I think his record will stand up very well.
Now let me respond veiy directly to the three points raised by my friend. I do not think he knows what he is talking about because when he reads Hansard he will find out, as he said, that the Canadian dollar had not lost 25 per cent during his period. Rather the dollar went up 25 per cent vis-a-vis the Americans.
What I said in my speech is as follows. In 1986, when this deal was first announced and being worked out, the dollar was at about 75 to 76 cents U.S. It went as high as 90 cents. In other words, it had appreciated over 25 per cent during the period that this deindustrialization started and had put that anchor around the necks of Canadians. That is all I said. Well, thank God the dollar is coming down. They finally started to listen to us.
The interest rates are coming down and the dollar is coming down, and why they have increased the interest rates five out of the last six weeks in Canada is beyond me. Do we not want a lower dollar to create jobs here? Members from the other side of the House are calling for it, and that member over there has too. So when he said the dollar has lost 25 per cent, he is wrong. The dollar went up more than 25 per cent. I hope he gets his mathematics straight.
Then he said General Motors shut down some plants in Canada but they also shut them down in the United States, why should we worry? Look at the figures in the last three years. Canadian auto jobs in parts and assembly have been lost at two and one-third times the rate in the U.S. We know there has been a recession. We know there is rationalization going on, but why should Canada lose jobs more quickly than the United States. That is not what we are about.
Then he talked about the vaunted trade figures. When this government across the way took office in 1984, Canada had a current account surplus of some $20 billion. Today we are in deficit. In the last quarter of last year we had an $8.1 billion current account deficit, which is a record in the history of Canada, and it surpassed even the previous record of $7.5 billion in the quarter preceding that.
March 13, 1992

If this is the vaunted economic performance of this government on the international playing field, then my goodness they are wearing blinders and blinkers. Canadians just do not believe you, sirs, on the other side when you tell us you are doing well and that you have been good stewards of Canada's future.
Unemployment in Canada went up to 10.6 per cent. Unemployment in the United States is at 7.1 per cent. That is who we are competing with, and what are you doing to help us get those jobs back? You are naive and you have not given us a level playing field. Please start looking at individual industries. How can you work with them to make sure they have equal opportunities that our American counterparts do to get jobs? Do not give us another of these pigs in a poke like you gave us, that it was not properly negotiated. They cannot even give us binding dispute of the Honda issue. We need binding settlement of that but we cannot get it.
I wish one of those people across there would show us how we can get any resolution of the Honda dispute without the ministers going to Washington on bended knee and prostrating themselves, asking for a favour of the United States government. That is the only way they are going to get it.
That is a great negotiating position.
That has put us in a position here in Canada that I as a Canadian am not proud to be in, and this is why changes have to be made.

Mr. Speaker I do, indeed, thank you.
I have heard the saying that the sins of the father are sometimes visited upon the son. But we have an extension here today from the hon. member for Mississauga South who wants to visit whatever sins there might be, either real or perceived, from one brother to another. I do not know how long they are going to go on on this particular tack.
The member for Mississauga South says: "Some people would think we are not capable of running a countiy." Well, I would like to have on record now that I am one of those who believes that this government has not been capable, is not capable, and will not be capable

of running Canada. All you have to do is look at their track record.
The hon. member for Mississauga South said that he was a little bit confused at what the member from Willowdale was saying. Contrary to that, I am not confused at all, but I would like the hon. member from Willowdale to make one further comment.
The member mentioned the auto industry. [Translation]

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, on a point of order. I think that the time for questions and comments is over and we must now move on to debate.
Two seconds.

I will take up the 42 seconds, if you do not mind, and the 42 seconds will be in the form of a question, which is specifically this. If we indeed were sold down the river with this free trade deal, I would like your comments, Mr. Member, through you, Mr. Speaker-
Your time is over, thank you.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the motion that we are debating today, the motion from the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona:
Thai, in the opinion of this House, Canada should withdraw from the negotiations concerning a North American free trade agreement, give notice of withdrawal from the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, and pursue a global trade strategy not based on making the planet an unfettered playground for the multinational corporate elite.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: What does that mean precisely?

Well, if the hon. member would allow me to proceed I will explain.
There have been plenty of reports, including even the speech of the last speaker from the Liberal Party, that have pointed out the failures of the free trade agreement and the likely failures of the North American free trade agreement. There have been plenty of reports that have shown that the only beneficiaries of it, the only reliable beneficiaries, are the multinational corporations.

March 13, 1992
Supply
I do not intend to rehearse all those arguments because there are some other points that should be made in this debate concerning the alternative possibilities. I will come to them a little bit farther along, but I want to give simply one of the major reasons for not renegotiating but abrogating the free trade agreement.
The free trade agreement places Canadian law subordinate to American law. That is to say, according to the free trade agreement in title I, section 102, Relationship of the Agreement to United States Law, page 1853 states:
(a) United States Laws to Prevail In Conflict-No provision of the Agreement, nor the application of any such provision to any person or circumstances, which is in conflict with any law of the United States shall have effect.
Fair enough, if that is going to be a two-way street, but it is not. The agreement elsewhere in volume 2, schedule part A, article 103, Extent of Obligation on page 2 states:
The Parties to this Agreement shall ensure that all necessary measures are taken in order to give effect to its provisions including their observance, except as otherwise provided in this Agreement by state, provincial and local governments.
In other words, American laws are totally protected from being reduced or set aside or hindered by the agreement. Canadian laws have no such protection in the agreement. It is a monstrous trick to subordinate Canada to the White House and to the American corporations. That is the reason why our party, at its convention last year, adopted the necessity of abrogating the free trade agreement and why that is the position that our party leader has consistently upheld.
That is the position of our party, as restated before then and since then many times by our leader, by our spokesman on international trade and by other members of this party. Since the government is hard-hearted on it and the Liberal Party waffles on it, I want to look at two of the reasons given for entering and maintaining the free trade agreement in order to dispose of them.
One of the reasons given is that it will help the poor Mexican workers. The Prime Minister loves to get up with flippant sarcasm and and say "Why are Canadians objecting to losing jobs? Don't you want to help the poor Mexicans?". It is well known that the Prime Minister does not give two hoots for the situation of jobless Canadians, therefore there is no reason to suppose that he has the slightest interest in helping jobless Americans or under-employed Americans or jobless Mexicans either or the under-employed ones.
The fact is that there is plenty of evidence to show that the total policies of the American and Canadian banks, the American and Canadian corporations and the American and Canadian governments are not increasing the employment opportunities and the pay opportunities for Mexicans, they are decreasing them. I quote from a paper done last year by Jorge Calderone Salazar on "Free Trade Agreement: Democracy and National Sovereignty in Mexico". This is what he says is needed. I will not cover the whole paper.
Serious negotiations on foreign debt should begin immediately, particularly with regard to the debt to the U.S. and Canadian banks in accordance with a proposal to reduce substantially the interest rate and the principle.
Since a well-known supporter of the free trade agreement, Diane Francis, purported to report Audrey McLaughlin otherwise, she has written a letter to the Financial Post on December 3 as follows:
Dear Editor:
In your October 26th edition, you published extracts from a lengthy and wide-ranging interview between myself and Diane Francis. On page 1 of the same issue, Ms. Francis draws some conclusions, among them that the New Democrats have softened their position on the free trade agreement. This conclusion is not accurate. Our party continues to oppose the deal and maintains the position that it ought to be abrogated. A New Democratic Party government would use the six-month provisions contained in the agreement to notify the United States of our intention to cancel the deal.
His position is that none of this trade deal will benefit Mexico so long as it has to pay out more than it takes in on the debt. He goes on to say:
Recent experience shows that it is perfectly feasible for Mexico to negotiate a framework agreement with the United States and Canada, similar to the one signed by Mexico with the European Economic Community on April 26, 1991. This is a road that needs to be explored in order to arrive at within a few years the formulation of a policy that is beneficial to the people of Mexico.
We have heard the judgment of Senator Calderone and many others, as well as ours, that the free trade agreement is not intended to help Mexican workers or campesina. It will not and in fact it cannot.

March 13, 1992

The second argument, of course, which is more popularly used is that Canada is too weak to stand alone against the United States. We have a population of only 26 million or so and they have 10 times as many. They have 100 times as much money and so people like the hon. minister who led off this morning for the government side are saying in effect that whatever the United States wants will inevitably happen, so if we cannot lick them, we had better join them.
That is the attitude of the banks, the large corporations of Canada and the government which they control through the Business Council on National Issues. They decided to join the American corporations in exploiting all the peoples of Canada, the United States and Mexico and, of course, intending to go beyond that. It is the Mexican workers and campesinos who are making known that they want allies against the kind of thing that the North American free trade agreement represents.
My point is that Canadians, who now in the majority oppose the free trade agreement according to the polls, are not alone in this matter. We are no longer isolated up in the frozen north. As has been acknowledged across the way, we have fax machines, we have jet planes, we communicate with the 380 million strong nationals south of American border and in the Caribbean.
A year ago when I went to the state of Morelos to observe their strange election practice of not allowing secret voting, I also met with some trade unionists in Mexico. The burden of their remarks to me was that we need an international bill of rights for labour.
Mr. Speaker, I see you are signalling to me a time limit. Can you tell me how much more time I have?
One minute.
I thought we had 20 minutes to speak.
Yes, you have 20 minutes.

As I was saying, they are asking for the kind of international labour rights that have been written into the agreement in the European Community but are absolutely rejected by the President of the United States, the President of Mexico and Prime Minister Mulroney of
Supply
Canada as part of the agreement. We are told: "You will come along and get those later, maybe".
In October the New Democratic Party sent me to Zacatecus to a meeting that was concurrent with the meeting of the trade ministers. It was a meeting of the Action Canada network, the counterpart networks from the United States, from Mexico, and a number of other political, academic and labour figures from Mexico.
At that meeting we adopted guidelines for a three nation movement for a citizens' alternative development program. I will mention a few of the points on which we agreed; that we should cancel or reduce Mexico's $100 billion debt to foreign banks; that we should cancel the free trade agreement between Canada and the United States; that we should equalize people's conditions across the three countries in work: wages, safety and democratic unions; in the community living conditions; health and education for migrant workers, equal rights with other workers. We should establish equality of women with men across the three countries. Each country should control its own culture, education, communication system and so on.
I will not take the time to list all of the matters on which we agreed. My point is that they are looking for allies among Canadians and they are finding them.
Two weeks ago I attended a meeting in Peru, sent by the NDP, a meeting of the Sao Paolo Forum, a group of Latin American and Caribbean parties that oppose U.S trade domination. They invited the NDP and the NDP sent me. I do not know whether they invited the Liberals. The Liberals were invited to the meeting I attended in Zacatecus but they did not send anyone. I did not see any Liberals at the meeting in Lima but I cannot say whether they were invited.
The people who invited me asked me to describe the deceptions used by the Prime Minister and this government to hoodwink the Canadian people into returning the government of the free trade agreement in the last election. They asked me to outline the damage done by the free trade agreement in the last three years which I did.
They want Canadians as allies in their struggles with the United States. They want our experience of free

Supply
trade, our knowledge of the United States. They want our trade and they want our voice in international affairs.
My point is that we are not alone. Not only the Latin Americans, including the Mexicans, but in the United States a growing group is advocating opposition to the free trade agreement. The AFL-CIO has registered its view. Many specific unions and locals have, church groups have, academic figures have. There is also a mounting campaign there to have a publicly administered and a publicly funded health insurance scheme like the Canadian one, which the free trade advocates would like to destroy by giving American corporations the right to manage Canadian hospitals and other institutions.
Besides that we have allies in Canada. The position of the Canadian Labour Congress is quite clear in opposition to the free trade agreement. We have research groups such as the Latin American Working Group and the Ecumenical Coalition for Economic Justice, which used to be called GATT-fly, which for many years have been exploring relationships with the Mexicans in preparation for the kind of bad deal that has been foisted upon us.
We have the churches, many of whose Canadian leaders, especially Roman Catholic ones, have spoken against the trade deal. I want to quote John Paul II, not on the trade deal of course, on which he has not spoken to my knowledge, but on a basic principle that was appealed to by the member for Winnipeg Transcona. The Pope said: "What is the origin of all the evils to which Rerum Novarum wished to respond, if not a kind of freedom, which in the economic and social activity cuts itself off from the truth about man". In other words, what the Pope has been teaching, as his predecessors did, is that unbridled market relationships without any regard for the need of people as individual persons is contrary to his teaching.
As one who does not regard the Pope as infallible, I would say that this and many other things that he has said are well worth listening to, including his encyclical Centesimal Anno.
I want to point out that there are proposals circulating in Canada, some of them endorsed by the NDP already and others under study, for an alternative version, an alternative policy, for example, on investment which would mean that the rights of people are to assert sovereignty over their economies, to choose their own
development priorities, reject the principle of national treatment for foreign investors and instead assert the right of sovereign states to enforce regulations governing the activities of transnational corporations. It goes on to detail them further.
It has an alternative policy on services, for developing service industries which would rule out national treatment and the right of establishment for foreign investors. Instead it will allow sovereign peoples to set rules governing which services could be provided by TNCs and which services would be allocated to domestic firms. This has been circulated for a year by the Ecumenical Coalition for Economic Justice and is being studied widely.
It continues:
An alternative policy for intellectual property such as drug patents.
An alternative view of intellectual property rights treats patents and copyrights as privileges rather than absolute rights. A development centred policy on intellectual property rights would recognize the sovereign right of countries to establish their own patent and copyright systems to enforce generic drug laws, to adapt technology to uses as appropriate to their stage of development, to exclude inappropriate technology from their borders and to resist pressures for global harmonization of patent laws in TNC interests.
Finally I want to mention their comments on agriculture.
An alternative approach to agriculture would begin with a recognition of people's right to basic food self-reliance. Countries have the right to protect themselves from the dumping of food commodities on to world markets at prices that are below the cost of production.
It is crucial to distinguish between subsidies that systematically encourage over-production and export dumping and subsidies designed to encourage food self-reliance, ecologically sound agricultural practices and other legitimate development objectives.
In conclusion, I want to say that there are alternative programs and policies being worked out not only by the NDP but by many groups across Canada who oppose the free trade agreement and the North American free trade agreement.
If we had been given fuller information by the government during the negotiations of both those agreements, if we had been given the information reports that the government swore to give to us, year by year, about the progress, we would be better able to mount those studies now. But because of the secrecy in which this government conducts its policies, refusing even to let Parliament know what is being resolved in our names, the work
March 13, 1992

has been slow, but it is progressing and it is getting wider and wider circulation.
I also wish to refer to a document that is being worked on by a group within my own constituency in which they want to mount a public statement around five points:
1.	Cancel the free trade deal-and they give detail on that.
2.	Let us put Canadians to work now.
3.	Fair taxes will give us the money we need.
4.	Strengthen our social services.
5.	Canadians need a say in developing our economy nationally and locally.
So in reiteration I want to quote again the motion of the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona:
That, in the opinion of this House, Canada should withdraw from the negotiations concerning a North American free trade agreement, give notice of withdrawal from the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, and pursue a global strategy not based on making the planet an unfettered playground for the multinational corporate elite.
In short, Mr. Speaker, dump the deal.

Mr. Speaker, I am quite interested in the member's speech. I am pleased that he was down in Mexico while negotiations were taking place on the free trade agreement.
Bearing in mind that the Government of Mexico is pressing this agreement with the United States and is prepared to negotiate with the United States alone, is it his view that Canada should not be at the table, that Canada should let the Americans and the Mexicans negotiate their own free trade agreement, and that we should not be anywhere close to the Mexicans? Should we not be there advising the Mexicans as to what they might want to look out for if they are making a deal with the Americans? Would he not think that we ought to extend our good offices and our assistance to the Mexicans?
Supply
Is it his policy and the policy of his party that we should just walk away from the table on the North American free trade agreement that is presently being negotiated with the Mexicans and not do anything?
That is my first question. My second question is, bearing in mind that we are quite proud of our medicare system, does he not think that by being in a trade agreement with the Americans and doing a great deal of business with them, increasing trade every year, a very substantial increased volume since 1988, that we influence American politics to some extent? As he pointed out, even some of the American unions are trying to stop our free trade agreement with the United States, that that agreement is not persuading Americans to perhaps have public medicare themselves? Does he not think that trade is an influential way that we can extend the good offices of Canada to the rest of the world?

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member as usual misrepresents what I am saying by suggesting that I am against trade. What the NDP opposes is not trade but we oppose putting all our eggs in one basket and giving the key to it to the President of the United States.
We can offer advice to the Mexicans. I have been doing it and the Prime Minister has been doing it. Some of my advice was more truthful than his, when he went down there and told them that the free trade agreement created 250,000 new jobs in the first year in Canada.
We can continue to offer advice, but I do not want Canada to cede some more of our sovereignty, especially to a government that is as illegitimate as the government of President Salinas. He only gained the presidency by corrupting the last election in such an extraordinary way that even the Organization of American States objected to it. They simply stopped the counting when they found that the opposition party was ahead, and a week later they produced figures to show that Salinas was ahead. I do not want Canada subordinate to an agreement with that kind of dictatorial ruler, who sends the police out to smash trade unions and to assassinate academics or church people who oppose him.
I do not want Canada sitting in those meetings, because our Prime Minister has shown that he has a great weakness for giving the Americans anything they

March 13, 1992
Supply
ask for. American Express wanted greater banking rights in Canada than the banks have; he gave it to them. What he got for it in return, I do not know. What he got for Canada, he has never told us. So I do not want that kind of weak-kneed giveaway being carried on in the free trade negotiations with the U.S. and Mexico.
As to increasing trade with the U.S., no. We have too many eggs in that basket already. I want us to increase trade with the Latin American countries, with the Caribbean. According to today's report, the GATT authority has said that the North American free trade agreement will hinder trade to the disadvantage of Caribbean and Latin American countries. They will be losers as a result of the North American free trade agreement. Though we have not had a chance to read the full report, I think they might well be right in that perception. It certainly is the perception of the people that I met in Lima two weeks ago. I would say we have to do our best to make GATT a more democratic organization than it is and the United Nations a more democratic organization than it is, rather than being so cowardly as just to throw our lot in with the guy who used to be the head of the CIA, President Bush.

I listened carefully to the member from Spadina speak, and he started off by saying he would cancel the free trade agreement, but then he went on to put forward a list of alternative approaches to the United States, which would presumably be much more beneficial to Canada's agenda.
Some of the proposals he is putting forward sound quite reasonable, and with a strong negotiator, I think a lot of those proposals would be attainable. Does he not think it would be a much more constructive or a less disruptive process to first try to advance his amendments, his constructive alternatives, and see if he can sell them? What if he did? What if he could make those amendments that he just cited today to the free trade agreement? What if, through a proper explanation and a strong leadership, a future president accepted those conditions?
I, for example, have never felt comfortable with the area of the free trade agreement related to water. I have always wanted a one page special protocol letter saying water is exempt from this deal. Make no mistake about it, it should be a separate negotiation.
We have never tried because we have a Prime Minister, basically, who has gone along with most of what the Americans want. But we may be blessed with a leader eventually that will say: "Hey, if you want to keep this in place, here is what we need." Would that not be a more constructive way to go?

I thank the hon. member for a very relevant question. He did, however, miss part of what I said. The President of the United States and the President of Mexico and the present Prime Minister of Canada have already publicly refused, a year ago, to consider any labour or environmental matters in the free trade agreement. They have rejected the very concept of having any such things in. They have gone so far along with the agreement that the only way we can preserve the possibility of what the member has suggested is by withdrawing from the agreement now.
Second, and again I made this point clear in my speech, what I want is that we should negotiate these things with all countries, not trying, as the Prime Minister once rightly perceived, as a mouse to negotiate with the elephant. Before he was converted to free trade he said it would be like the mouse sleeping with the elephant. He was right then and wrong ever since.
We should be negotiating with all the countries of this hemisphere, and we have the possibility of doing that. They want us to. They have asked us to. We should be negotiating with the whole hemisphere, and that would give us the clout necessary to get the United States to come to reason or else to elect a president who would come to reason.

speakeroldname: Mr. Andre Plourde (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for International Trade
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the opposition motion seems to be an overreaction to the problems that Canada is having in its trade relations with the United States. Unfortunately, it takes no account of all the positive aspects in Canada-U.S. relations.
Mr. Speaker, it is true that last week was not easy. We would be lying if we did not admit that we were
March 13, 1992

disappointed by Washington's decision on Honda and softwood lumber. We are very disappointed, in fact. We do not believe that these decisions are justified, but we are convinced that we will win in the end, as we did with pork. The stakes were considerable then. It took time, but the facts proved us right. That is why the government is convinced that the policy adopted seven years ago was right and that it remains just as valid today.
For those of you who might have forgotten, let me remind you of the reasons. From the outset, we had three objectives in our negotiations with the United States.
First, we wanted to improve access to the American market for our products and services. We wanted to encourage Canadian producers to break out of the straitjacket imposed by the small domestic market, to retool and to take on the world market. The American market was not an end in itself but a starting point for a greater presence on world markets. We accepted the fact that increased American competition on our own market would encourage Canadians to discipline themselves and to restructure in order to face world competition.
Second, we wanted secure access to the U.S. market. We wanted to be able to give as much assurance as possible to Canadian entrepreneurs who decided to enter the American market that they would not be the victims of arbitrary, ill-considered decisions. We wanted our economic and trade relations with the United States to be protected by rules agreed upon by both parties and uniformly applied.
Finally, we wanted to entrench this improved secure access in a legal framework, with institutional provisions and dispute settlement mechanisms that would go a long way to making us equal partners, governed by rules and procedures accepted by both parties.
Noble words, grandiose objectives. Have they been achieved, Mr. Speaker? On the whole, yes. That is the conclusion which the government came to in 1987 and which it maintains today.
It is not naive but realistic. The international agreements have to do with improvements and compromises that were carefully negotiated. Only one criterion applied: Would the agreement be a tangible improvement over the previous status quo? Based on this criterion, the government concluded in 1987 that the
Supply
agreement negotiated was a marked improvement over
the status quo.
Furthermore, the Canadian people agreed with us in the 1988 election. None of the events in the last three and a half years have changed this assessment-not the verification of Honda cars nor softwood lumber, beer or magnesium. Are we indifferent to the difficulties experienced by Canada's auto workers, forestiy workers, miners and brewers? Certainly not, Mr. Speaker. Each of these instances is very disturbing, and we have always used all available resources and taken every opportunity to defend our interests and to help people in difficult situations. We will continue our efforts in this respect, and we will do so, with all the energy we have and all the recourse at our disposal.
The Prime Minister said this quite clearly to President Bush. The external affairs minister sent the same message to James Baker, as the trade minister did to Carla Hills and Barbara Franklin.
However, these disputes should be put into context, Mr. Speaker. Bilateral trade between Canada and the United States is now estimated at $256 billion. This represents three-quarters of our exports and two-thirds of our imports. About two million Canadians are directly dependent on this trade for their living, and millions more enjoy indirect benefits.
During the past 10 years, trade between Canada and the United States has gradually increased. In 1985, when Canadians started giving serious consideration to free trade, goods and services worth approximately $200 billion crossed the border. Since then, this type of trade has increased at an Baverage annual rate of 4 per cent. The rate may have been lower last year, Mr. Speaker, when the recession struck both economies, but trade should pick up as we come out of this recession. How do we know? It is what the statistics on investment in recent years tell us.
In fact, trade agreements are not only about current trade but about future investment. The purpose is to stimulate investment that will provide for sustained growth. In this respect, the free trade agreement remains a resounding success.
From 1986 to 1989, in other words, between the time the business community first acknowledged that Canadian-American economic relations were about to enter a new era, and the actual implementation of the agree-

March 13, 1992
Supply
ment, capital spending by businesses increased by an annual average of nearly 12 per cent. The recession put a brake on capital spending, which nevertheless totalled $80.2 billion in 1990 and $75.2 billion in 1991, and is expected to be around $74.1 billion in 1992. This kind of investment paves the way for a period of dynamic two-way trade and production activity that will be characteristic of the remainder of the 90s.
However, even today, as we gradually come out of the recession, there are encouraging signals. In 1991, there was a 3 per cent increase in the use of marketing services, an area of international trade that is experiencing very rapid growth.
Recession or not, trade between Canada and the United States is proceeding without incident. Every day, thousands of goods cross the border quickly and efficiently, on board trucks, trains and aircraft. Not more than 5 per cent of our two-way trade is affected by the various trade disputes. Without minimizing the importance of this 5 per cent, Mr. Speaker, it must be put into context.
Let me ask the real question, let us get to the bottom line. Setting aside the rhetoric, would we really be better off without the free trade agreement? The answer, Mr. Speaker, is no. The Americans are in a bad mood. They are in a recession and 1992 is an election year. For those of us who depend on trade, this is a particularly difficult combination. The United States are taking measures against several of their trade partners. Canada is not the only target, not even the main one. Japan remains their number one target, although Europe, Brazil and other countries are also affected. We are not thrilled about the situation, Mr. Speaker. Neither are the Japanese, the Europeans or the Brazilians. That is why global trade standards must be established to provide a clearer and stricter set of rules and prevent excessive protectionism on the part of the United States and also Europe and Japan. While Canada is generally hit first and the hardest by the American strain of this virus called "unfair trade practices", protectionism is not exclusive to the United States.
The United States has a peculiar way of defining fair trade practices and the strength of their economy is such
that it can force its vision of things on others, even when inaccurate.
The fair trading system advocated by the United States rests on the premise that any producer for whom foreign competition creates hardship can plead his case before the authorities. He must show that the foreign competitor has somehow taken an unfair advantage of the United States. Over the years, the American Congress has developed numerous procedures through which American producers can vent their frustrations. In some cases, that is all it takes, but in others, the system provides for temporary or permanent penalties.
Whatever the outcome of these procedures, they are harmful, Mr. Speaker. They have a cooling effect on trade and investment and they erode investors' confidence. The big losers are the American economy and consumers, but we are also hurt.
The American system has gradually become uncontrollable. Once out, it is hard to get the genie back into the bottle. U.S. trade policy is marked by a lack of vision and leadership. The gap between the rhetoric and U.S. action is widening constantly. The U.S. is overly fond of preaching free trade while giving its own subjective and changeable definition of fair trade.
The answer is not to give tit for tat, because, as I said earlier, we often end up harming our own interests. The answer lies in negotiating international trade rules. We know that, and so does the U.S. In fact, U.S. representatives freely admit they need proper regulations more than any other country because their own system is too vulnerable to special interests.
That is why we have the free trade agreement and why we must keep demanding better and clearer regulations. It is also why we must have global trading standards and a three-way agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada. We must seize every opportunity to obtain agreement on a set of regulations and on better mechanisms for dispute settlement. It is not a matter of one or the other. We need both to achieve one and the same objective: a more open, more predictable and more stable trading system.
However, the best cure for the current protectionist trend will be tangible proof that the recession is coming to an end, especially in the United States. We have reason to be optimistic. U.S. company reports are improving. Mortgages are being refinanced at lower rates.
March 13, 1992

Consumers have more money to spend, and the private sector is eager to supply the demand.
Any recovery in the U.S. economy will improve our prospects and strengthen confidence in the economy. Once again, Canada has realized that its well-being depends on that of its neighbour. However, once American consumers start spending again, we will be there to benefit, and we will be in a better position to take advantage of these opportunities. The past five years of adjustment and restructuring will have been worthwhile. Canadian entrepreneurs, now stronger and more competitive, will be able to take advantage of our improved access under the free trade agreement.
There are people who maintain that the agreement has made us a favourite target of U.S. protectionists and that it has removed our defences. Now who is being naive?
Anyone who is successful becomes a target, Mr. Speaker. U.S. interests will always take an aggressive stand against imports. Americans are no different from anyone else in this respect. Obviously exports are more readily acceptable than imports. Any country would prefer one-way free trade. However, trade with other countries is a source of wealth, and both exports and imports are a way to stimulate growth.
It is a fact that Canada still shows a substantial surplus in its trade with the United States. Our annual exports to the United States have increased by $5 billion since 1988, the year before the implementation of free trade. In comparison, we have a general trade deficit of $7.7 billion with the rest of the world. This tells us that the free trade agreement is working well and that it helps preserve Canadian jobs. According to the agreement, customs duties will not be fully phased out until 1998, but exporters in both countries have already applied for accelerated elimination of certain customs tariffs between our two countries. So far, Canadian companies have requested and obtained two series of accelerated tariff reductions which have made it possible to eliminate customs duty on nearly 1,000 tariff items worth a total of $8 billion in bilateral trade. A third series is now under way.
Critics are confusing Canadians by blaming the free trade agreement for lay-offs in our manufacturing sector. One fact worth mentioning is that the current decline in employment in the manufacturing sector is
Supply
more or less on a par with the number of jobs lost during the 1982 recession, when there was no free trade.
The loss of jobs in the manufacturing sector is not a recent phenomenon. In 1972, about 22 per cent of Canadians worked in the manufacturing sector. By 1990, this percentage had dropped to 15.9 per cent. The displacement of jobs from the manufacturing sector to the service sector is a phenomenon that we share with most developed countries, including Japan. It reflects the impact of the broad restructuring of our global economy.
Furthermore, increased employment in the service sector has more than compensated for the decline in jobs in the manufacturing sector. Administrative, professional and technical positions accounted for one-third of the growth in employment between 1971 and 1981, compared to 77 per cent between 1981 and 1986. According to Statistics Canada, these job categories will account for more than half of the new jobs created in the 1990s. Our manufacturing sector is neither dead nor seriously threatened. It is misleading to mention only jobs losses as proof that our secondary sector is declining. The total value of production in constant dollars and the manufacturing share of the total economy are more accurate indicators. According to these indicators, our manufacturing sector is maintaining itself.
In fact, employment increased in telecommunications and transportation equipment, aerospace and computer software. Since 1988, exports of Canadian finished products in such things as aerospace, industrial machinery, transportation equipment and chemicals have risen by about $4 billion.
Let me add, Mr. Speaker, that the free trade agreement is attracting foreign investment to Canada, investments that go to Canadian manufacturing and create jobs in Canada. Net direct foreign investment is positive for the first time in 16 years. The free trade agreement has encouraged Canadian companies to reduce their investments in the United States and to invest more in Canada.
Inevitably, the largest bilateral trade relationship in the world has tensions and problems, especially in a recession. Because of the present recession, the two governments have difficulty managing the bilateral trade relationship, and this is an election year in the United States. But the free trade agreement has protected Canadian companies from the arbitrary and unfair application of trade remedies provided in American law.

March 13, 1992
Supply
Final decisions on anti-dumping and countervailing duties can now be examined by a special binational panel.
We also have the right to request a binational review of any change to existing laws and regulations on countervailing and anti-dumping duties.
In conclusion, Mr. Speaker, the United States cannot apply new trade laws to Canada unless these laws comply with GATT and the spirit and letter of the free trade agreement. No other country has such protection from unfair trade action.
Ask our pork producers. The special panels under the free trade agreement saved them $20 million last year by eliminating U.S. countervailing duties.
We are determined to protect Canadian interests and to have the spirit and letter of the free trade agreement respected, because it remains the best guarantee for our trade relations.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to the member's speech and, quite frankly, I have to question him on a couple of things.
First of all, he talked about increased foreign investment. Foreign investment in this country in the last couple of years, especially in the area of manufacturing, has shrunk dramatically. That is one of the reasons why our smaller and medium sized businesses are having difficulties, there is such a shortage of capital in the market. So I do not really think that free trade did anything to enhance foreign investment in this country.
Not true.
It really has not.
In my riding $800 million in Dow Chemical.

I take the hon. member's point, Dow Chemical, $800 million, and I give him full recognition. But there are 1,700,000 businesses in this country and he cites to me Dow Chemical. I will give him Dow Chemical, but the bottom line is that because there is so little foreign capital coming into this country and because we have such a deficit and debt to service, that has reduced the availability of capital within our banking system.
I will bet you dollar to doughnuts that nine out of ten entrepreneurs who you approach on the street today will tell you that they are finding it very difficult to get additional lines of credit for more capital. That is just the simple truth of it.
Regarding the issue at hand, this free trade agreement, the more I listen to the government side of this House, the more I am happy to be on the record that I campaigned against the free trade agreement, especially chapters 14 and 16. The minister responsible for the environment will know well that most of her constituents, if they had a chance today, would not support her position on this free trade agreement. They would reverse it.
The point that I wanted to ask the member specifically about, and I am reading here and I do not want to cite exclusively from Mel Hurtig's book The Betrayal of Canada because there are some things in it that I do not go along with-
What an authority.
No, I qualified my remarks.
Not true.

But I do. This is not a quote from Mel Hurtig, this is a quote from an American research magazine. It says that the majority of branch plants in Canada are not permitted by their U.S. parent to export into the U.S. market and compete with them there. Among the long list of "not free to export" companies are Avon, Revlon, Gillette, Mennen, Noxema, Max Factor, Jergens and Lever Brothers.
Does the hon. member not think that there could be or should be some kind of an instant audit and review or a midway review about how this free trade agreement is really affecting the day to day life of the manufacturing industry in this country.
Cannot the government see that there is a global recession and there are some difficulties in the world that we are naturally being affected by. Does the member not think that it would be a good idea to strike a committee to do an audit and a review to see what negative impacts, and maybe positive in certain areas, we
March 13, 1992

can find so that we know exactly what is going on with this free trade agreement and then we can go from there?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for International Trade
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as a parliamentarian with eight years experience, I think that I can give an answer to my hon. colleague from the Liberal Party. Before taking up politics, I was an industrialist and over the course of 28 years, I have worked to set up three businesses. By 1988, they had the capacity to export to the U.S. I extend an invitation to my hon. colleague from the Liberal Party to come and visit my riding of Kamou-raska-Riviere-du-Loup. He will see that employment has doubled in these businesses established in a city with a population of only 13,500. I am not talking about big cities like Toronto, Montreal or Vancouver, but Riviere-du-Loup. The free trade agreement has enabled small business to seek new markets in the U.S.
The hon. member quoted a book. Let me quote in turn Mrs. Elisabetta Bigsby, vice-president of the Royal Bank International Trade Centre. I have learned a few things in politics. The politicians in this House are all bright people, but there are others outside these walls and we must listen to them. In a speech she gave in Quebec city earlier this week, Mrs. Bigsby, vice-president of the Royal Bank International Trade Centre said that Quebec has done the right thing in supporting free trade. That is not a politician talking, or a reporter or an author. I think we should believe Mrs. Bigsby.
She was the keynote speaker at a conference lunch organized by the association of Quebec business women. They carry some weight, as you know, Mr. Speaker. She said, and I quote:
When you depend on a single market with relatively few products, as we do in Canada-
She did not say Quebec, she said Canada.
-you are in for a bad time when the economy of this buyer country slows down. That is why diversification must be emphasized, be it geographic diversification or product diversification.
Here in Canada, we often blame high labour costs for our international trade failures. In Germany, labour costs are even higher than here and Germany is still a world power.
Supply
