We can give two good examples of Quebec companies-SR Telecom and Vetements Louis Gareau. SR Telecom exports 90 per cent of the communication satellites it produces.
Vetements Louis Gareau makes high quality sportswear and exports all over the world. Those are perfect examples of companies which, even with the high cost of labour, have found free market niches and have penetrated the export markets.
Mrs. Bigsby mentions that 50 years ago international trade represented 20 per cent of all commercial transactions while it represents more than 50 per cent today.
She concludes by saying:
Since international trade is now done between blocs like the EEC, Asia, South America or the members of the free trade agreement, Quebec was right in approving this Agreement which can only be good for the province.
If I may, Mr. Speaker, I would like to answer another question. The member mentioned that I did not talk about investments in my statement. I'll have him know that Pratt & Whitney, for example, made investments of approximately $130 million in Halifax and that Louisiana Pacific Panel Products Limited invested $65 million in Point Tupper, Nova Scotia.
Pratt & Whitney Canada also invested $1.8 billion in Longueuil, Halifax and Mississauga, Ontario. Papeterie Daishowa invested $130 million in Quebec city and another company invested $120 million in Riviere-Beau-dette, Quebec.
Now for the investments in Ontario; there is Dupont-$600 million in Kingston, Trenton, Ajax, Whitby and Sarnia; Bois Cascades Canada-$90 million in Keno-ra, and I am only talking about investments made in Ontario, not in Quebec. Kimberly-Clark-$60 million in Terrace Bay, Ontario; Goodyear Canada-$370 million in Napanee.
I could go on and on but I will stop here and say this: it is easy to forget. We never take the past enough into account; is the past not a taken of things to come?

Mr. Speaker, I want to say at the outset that I am going to share my time with the hon. member for Winnipeg South Centre.

March 13, 1992
Supply
I should comment at the outset that this is an opposition motion by the New Democratic Party, moved by the member for Winnipeg Transcona. Earlier in the day he made reference to the member for Vancouver Quadra not carrying on the fight of his life. That member was the leader of the Liberal Party of Canada during the last election. It was a fight, a tremendous fight.
But I want to point out that if the leader of the New Democratic Party had attacked the government with the persistence that we did, then the government would have been turfed out of office. But rather than attack the government that is responsible for the free trade debacle, members of the NDP attacked the Liberals because they were determined that they would be the official opposition. But had they attacked the government and the government was turfed out, they could very well have ended up as the official opposition. The Liberals would have been in power and we would have scrapped the free trade agreement at that time and we would not be in the mess we are in today.
I thought I would get some applause from the New Democratic benches but, Madam Speaker, there is not one here to take part in their own debate.
I take part in this debate today as a Canadian who has witnessed first hand the systematic dismantling of this nation by a government whose loyalties are to the rich and the powerful, loyalties that should be toward this nation and her people, but loyalties that have been redirected toward interests outside of Canada, corporate interests whose objective is power and financial domination.
Canadians are now paying a terribly high price; high unemployment, factories closing and moving to the United States and Mexico, our social systems being dismantled and medicare eroded. The free trade agreement has stripped Canada of the power to intervene and protect our cultural, economic and social programs. In fact I have to wonder just how long it will be until medicare is hit with a countervail action by the United States.
This could be the scenario. A United States firm raises the issue that its company is paying its employees' health benefits and a competing firm in Canada is taking its
markets. Because Canadians have a current health plan that covers everyone, then I suggest that such a countervail will take place.
This free trade agreement is an unmitigated disaster, even worse than we had forecast. The U.S. trade remedy laws are intact and indeed supersede the agreement, but here in Canada we made many changes to our laws; changes to the unemployment insurance premiums, crop insurance, interest free loans on farm stored grain, the At and East, and the list goes on, all to accommodate the FTA. These are items that are brought about by various sectors of our economy due to the needs of our people, but items that could be misconstrued to be subsidies and subject to countervail by the U.S.
When we look at some of the actions by the U.S. since free trade came in, the countervail on our lumber, the fish issue on the west coast, the continuation of the export enhancement programs, in clear violation of the free trade agreement, our government does nothing. On March 18, 1991,1 laid out the procedures in an adjournment debate in this House, as reported at page 18640 of Hansard, to call for consultations on compensation under the free trade agreement but the Tories have done nothing. They have done nothing to protect Canadian grain farmers from the huge export subsidies in the U.S. These grain subsidies are driving our producers out of business and causing very low prices in the total grain sector.
In the softwood lumber case we had unrestricted access to the United States market for our lumber, for everything except prefabricated housing and plywood. Unrestricted access was negotiated under the GATT in the Tokyo round and given away under the free trade agreement. Now we have a government trying to throw up a smoke screen and speaking of retaliation. This is sheer hypocrisy.
I have said from the beginning of the FTA negotiations that it totally ignores the reality of the climatic zones and agricultural geography of North America.
As a life-long agriculturalist I contend that the FTA is clearly detrimental to the economic well-being of the Canadian agriculture sector. Mother nature alone dictates that there is no level playing field. Our physical loss
March 13, 1992

in Canadian agriculture, our climatic area, our soils and abundance of moisture have been completely ignored.
In 1987 the United States government identified Canadian marketing agencies and systems as a trade distorting structure. Yet our negotiators and the government have done nothing to protect our industry against continuing attacks from both inside and outside Canada. Not only have they recognized the differences in our physical base but they have now admitted the fact that input costs in Canada are 25 per cent higher in comparison to those in the United States. They have not admitted that either.
More than 80 food processing firms have closed in Canada since January 1989, 46 of those in Ontario alone. Over 80 food processing plants have closed since free trade came into Canada. By contrast, we see huge new hyper-plants becoming the norm in the United States. If one U.S. company can supply a particular type of ice-cream with only two huge plants in the whole country then we have to realize it could easily supply the smaller Canadian market also without much addition.
Consequently, by ignoring these differences and entering into a free trade agreement that did not specifically exclude the essential elements of our industry, Canada has been placed in an impossible situation by this government. The Canada-U.S.-Mexico free trade agreement would make this situation even worse, particularly in the area of food production and processing.
It is imperative Canadian people know what is going on in these negotiations. We currently see the Canadian dairy and poultry sectors under siege at the GATT due to the free trade agreement and the fall-out.
Time after time we have seen time honoured Canadian institutions established under statute of this House being traded away in secret, behind closed doors at the GATT, in the free trade agreement, and now in the Canada-U.S.-Mexico trade negotiations.
I am deeply concerned that on May 1, 1991 our trade minister threw his support behind the U.S. position that environmental concerns be excluded from the negotiations in the North American free trade agreement. They are ignoring global warming and the thinning of the ozone.
Supply
In June 1991 the same minister said that he wanted to see Canadian firms get the same access to the inexpensive Mexican labour pool as U.S. firms. Again they are ignoring the 1.5 million unemployed Canadians.
Just to give some indication of the differences in the wage rates, I have a chart here showing Mexican total compensation and minimum wage data. In 1980 the manufacturing sector in Mexico was paying $2.85 an hour. Now it is down to $2 an hour. In 1980 it was a $1.36 an hour in the Maquiladora manufacturing area. It is down to 99 cents an hour now. The minimum wage in 1980 was $1.21. It is now down to 59 cents. Is this what the minister had in mind when he is going to tap those huge labour pools?
I have to ask the government: If that is the case, what is it going to do to the standard of living in Canada and what opportunity does that present to 1.5 million unemployed Canadians?
On the other hand, we intend to show the people of Canada what is happening here. Because of that reason we have to know what is going on because the government is not going to tell us. Will we continue to allow foreign investors to siphon off huge dividends from our economy, from areas which exercise near monopoly positions in the market and have profits three times higher than those of their own United States operations? As we examine such instances do our competition laws apply, and what about the anti-trust legislation in the U.S.? Is it being enforced? I suggest not.
We are seeing a massive concentration of power in the hands of fewer and fewer trans-national corporations and the direction of this government is giving them the agenda to carry out their ambitions.
I am deeply concerned about the future of this nation, the people of this nation and their standard of living. In Mexico, as I pointed out earlier, the wages are far, far less. Yet the government keeps telling us we have to be more competitive with a nation whose wages are far below ours and are still going down.
Finally, what can I tell my grandchildren? I can only recall to them the era when I was their age, an era which put the needs of the people, the needs and welfare of the population, above the greed and the ambitions of huge corporate structures.

March 13, 1992
Supply
As a Canadian, I am very alarmed about what is happening in Canadian society today and what is happening to our structures, to our institutions. It is time the Government of Canada listened to the will of the people and stopped taking direction from the multinational corporations whose bottom line is profit and greed.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to put a question to my colleague across the way. Certainly I do this with no malice because he is a friend of mine and a colleague in Lambton county. Maybe we would want to talk about our home turf as far as the free trade agreement is concerned and about the multinationals in our area that he seemed to be berating a bit. Many people who live in his riding work for either Dupont, Shell, Cabot Carbon, Dow Chemical, Esso, ICI or Ethyl. All of them are multinationals that have contributed a great deal to our community. To my mind they are companies that we all respect. They helped to build our county and our city and provide the sound, economic situation we have there.
I would hope that he was not referring to them when he was talking about the multinationals that he seemed to be indicating were raping and pillaging Canada.
On a more specific note, the free trade agreement enacted a five-year countdown on petrochemicals and tariffs. In two more years after this one there could be no tariff on petrochemicals because there is a possibility in the free trade agreement, if we have mutual agreement on both sides, to have them removed completely.
I hear his party berating the situation, talking about the dollar and the dollar needing to be lowered to have this competitive advantage. Yet I say to my colleague and friend that the free trade agreement allowed the tariffs consistently, five years or less, to be removed. This definitely makes a much more competitive position for exporting that product to the United States. All the companies in our areas supported the free trade agreement. They thought it was good because it made them more competitive. What that means is stability of jobs for the people who work in his area. Many of them supplement their farming operations by working for these companies either on an hourly or on a salaried basis.
He might want to reply to that for those back home to understand exactly, not so much those where my friend comes from but maybe where his party comes from.

Madam Speaker, I am delighted to respond to my colleague from Sarnia-Lambton on this very issue. I should point out to him that the Esso Corporation, Imperial Oil Limited, first started out in the town of Petrolia which is in my riding. Oil was first discovered in North America in Lambton county. It was really the birthplace of the oil industry.
However, I see the difficulties it is going through. I think of those employees at Imperial Oil who walked out the door a couple of weeks ago with no prior notice whatsoever, having been given their pink slips. I see what is happening to the petrochemical industry in that area, as well as in western Canada. It is under pressure and in direct competition with the petrochemical industry on the Texas gulf coast. I just have to wonder what is going to happen here in the long term when it comes to the free trade agreement.
We have to recognize that when those companies came into Canada, under the automotive agreement they had to operate as responsible corporate citizens. The decisions had to be made in Canada for the benefit of the majority of Canadians. That is not happening today. It is one thing that has to happen. If companies based outside Canada are going to operate in Canada, they have to be brought to task, adhere to the principles that will meet the needs of this country whether it is the environment, the welfare of our people, or for the good of the country in general.
I should point out that I have documentation on one large firm that had sales of $4.3 billion in 1990. It sent $538,700,000 in dividends back to the parent company in the U.S. It borrowed $474 million to do that. It was a tax dodge. The Canadian consumers are going to pay back that loan and pay for the interest on it. We have to get back to basics here and make sure these corporations, these transnational corporations, act as responsible corporate citizens in this nation.

Madam Speaker, let me preface my comments with an opening remark. I suppose we could say with some certainty that the eyes of the nation are not exactly centred on the House of Commons, on this Friday afternoon debate. I say that with great regret because we are today dealing with what in my view is perhaps one of
March 13, 1992

the most important issues facing Canadians now and in the future, that is a trade policy that makes sense for Canadians.
The reason it is important is that the trade policy, if we would call it that, of the present government, is in shambles. It has come apart. The wheels have fallen off. The sides have collapsed and it is going nowhere except downhill.
Do you remember those bright days of 1988 and jobs, jobs, jobs? The Prime Minister was accurate in one sense. The jobs, jobs, jobs have all gone south. Some
400,000	of them have left this country in the past two years: manufacturing jobs in southern Ontario, the petrochemical industry in Alberta and fish processing plants on the west and east coasts, furniture factories in Manitoba, clothing and textile factories in Montreal. Name it. It is happening. The jobs have disappeared, not been added to.
We also saw clearly this week the great touchstone. I looked back at the record where the Prime Minister said on March 16, 1987 that our highest priority was to have an agreement that ended the threat to Canadian industry from U.S. protectionists who harassed and restricted our exports.
What have we been debating all this week? Harassment of the United States against some of our most critical industries: hydro power in Quebec, softwood lumber which affects every province across Canada, automobile industries in Ontario. If this were the highest priority then I think any honest judgment would indicate that it has been an abject failure. The reason is that it started out with a fundamentally flawed premise that we could tie our trade strategy to a continental approach. We can lock it into North America. We can put all our eggs in that basket. We can have a dispute settlement mechanism confined simply to North American trade and Canada would become the land of milk and honey. At the time we said it would not work that way. It has not worked that way. It defied the fundamental historic experience of Canada over the past 40 years in international trade that we have to work inside an international, multilateral framework to make it work. [DOT]
The unfortunate part of signing the free trade agreement is that we abandoned that approach. We sort of
Supply
turned it over to this North American cocoon. The real tragedy is that as the world changes, as we become more interdependent, the opportunity for trade development around the world is increasing and the Canadian opportunity to begin opening trade niches in eastern Europe, in the Russian republics, in parts of east Asia, in central and Latin America are expanding but we are not in a position to take advantage of them. Canadian trade in those areas is falling drastically behind.
One of the reasons is because of the free trade deal. We are putting handcuffs on ourselves. Limiting our ability to process our materials, limiting our ability to invest and give the kind of support to specialized Canadian industry to attract those markets is a direct result of the free trade agreement. We lost control over our own ability to have an industrial trade strategy to enable Canada to expand its markets around the world.
That was our contention during the debate of 1988. We were not arguing about lowering some tariffs because as Liberals we have been in favour of bringing down trade barriers around the world. What we were against was the price we had to pay under the free trade agreement to get that, a price on limiting investment, energy, industrial strategy, regional development. All those things that Canadians have used over the years to provide for a targeted, managed trade strategy we surrendered, we abandoned. We put a strait-jacket around ourselves and as a result our ability to respond to the burgeoning international trade opportunities is thereby limited.
We have seen in the debate this past week where time after time ministers of the Crown have got up to try to defend first the indefensible, which was the signing of a memorandum of understanding on softwood lumber in 1986, really one of the classic disasters. It makes the Battle of Dunkirk look like a victory by comparison.
I will never forget being in this House-some members were not here then-when the then minister of trade, the Hon. Pat Carney, arrived back from her vacation in Hawaii and declared to the House of Commons: "We have won a great victory" to the great applause of the Tory back benches. We had put a 15 per cent tax on ourselves, one of the great sort of ingenious solutions to a problem and in doing that, gave up the right to challenge the U.S. law at the GATT where we would have won the case and forced Americans to recognize that their trade law is wrong. We gave up an

March 13, 1992
Supply
opportunity to use the international forum to challenge U.S. law.
I have heard the minister of trade, the Prime Minister and all the other acolytes get up and say: "We have a dispute settlement mechanism under free trade. That will work for us". They do not complete the sentence. They do not complete the equation. The dispute settlement mechanism under the free trade agreement does not allow us to challenge U.S. trade law. We can only look at whether that trade law was properly administered or not. It is not a question of being able to say to the Americans: "You are introducing protectionist trade laws that can harass us". All we can say to them is: "Did you adjudicate it properly?"
It is not a trade dispute settlement mechanism when you cannot challenge a bad law that is killing our industry. When they get up and say: "Let's use trade dispute mechanisms", they are using it as a smokescreen.
We are saying that it is not a question of taking the free trade deal and saying: "Let's get rid of it", as our friends here are saying. What we have to do is look at that free trade agreement, see how it is affecting Canadian industry and sit down with the Americans and properly negotiate those parts which are doing damage to Canada. That is the practical response.
I am surprised, and perhaps some member of the New Democratic Party will explain to me that when we took that stand, it did not mean to say that. As members well know, our own critique of the free trade agreement, which I have just outlined, is there for all to see. It is a question of what do you do about it. We have stated our option-negotiate. If there is not enough negotiation, we will exercise the right to abrogate. It was a clear statement by our leader and by our party in convention three weeks ago.
I listened to the member from Winnipeg Transcona today who seemed to be saying that that is the wrong approach. I went back and read the statement by his leader, the hon. member for Yukon, in the Financial Post, who said and I quote, and the quote is right:
If elected, we will sit down with the Americans and say how can
we make this thing work. If not, we will give them six months notice
she said.
That is a very reasonable approach and I applaud the hon. leader of the New Democratic Party for taking it, but what I am wondering is why the member for Winnipeg Transcona jumps up and down, gnashes his teeth, spits pure venom against a policy that his own leader seems to be endorsing. Mind you, he is strange, Madam Speaker.
I want to come to one final point, if I may. I realize that we only have a short time of 10 minutes. The question is, where do you go from here? Clearly we are in a position where we have to look at alternatives. I simply want to return to the trade document that we put out during the 1988 election in terms of a Liberal trade policy. We said two fundamental things. A trade strategy for Canada must be an international trade strategy. It must work through the multinational forums. It must seek to diversify our markets and we must plan domestically the kinds of programs to support Canadian industry developing those markets.
That means working to ensure that fish processing plants can process fish in Canada so we can sell to the international markets. We will do it and that is one reason why free trade is not working for us. That means investing and giving special procurement rights to Canadian industry when they buy things from a government department in order to specialize and enhance their industrial research capacity. That is what we think has to be done so we can sell our manufactured products to Third World countries or to Russia, whether it is agricultural technology or environmental technology.
We believe in an international trade strategy. We believe that even in the case of the negotiations with Mexico and the United States, we are making a big mistake in limiting ourselves to that. The opportunity, for example, of developing a hemispheric trade policy, of incorporating the countries of the Caribbean, Latin and Central America in a broad-based trade arrangement, makes some sense because we balance out the interest. We do not fall into the hub and spoke philosophy of the Americans which is all roads lead to Washington.
We are trying, once again, to have a balanced forum in which various countries can apply equal leverage to make sure that the trade law in those areas applies equally to all countries and does not have a preferred
March 13, 1992

advantage for one strong economic power. I think this resolution would have been much better if we had a positive trade strategy, a constructive approach, not simply tearing up, throwing back, isolating ourselves, but one that looks to the future, one that looks at how this country can once again regain its capacity to be a leader in international trade and not a follower of continental trade policy.

Madam Speaker, I listened to my colleague and I want to ask him a very specific question. One of the concerns that I have always had about this free trade agreement has to do with the area related to our water resources. I have always had that concern because the chief negotiator for the United States, Clayton Yeutter, did his Ph.D. thesis in North American water management.
We have heard repeatedly from the government side of the House that water has nothing to do with this free trade agreement, yet we know that many Americans have a different view and there are also many lawyers in Canada who have a different view.
I was wondering if he could comment for a minute or two on what his views would be about water in the free trade agreement.

Madam Speaker, the issue of water was one that really became an important debate when this House was considering the free trade bill and the hearings that went on about it. What we basically pointed out was articles 408 and 409 where the United States acquired the right to perpetual access to Canadian resources. Under that we went back to the annex of what those included. It included water as part of the annex. We said that when and if the time came the Americans felt that water was a crucial resource that they were running out of-and, by the way, the time is drawing nigh, it is becoming increasingly a matter of more concern-that they could use the free trade agreement to make claim upon those water resources and that our ability to manage those resources and have our own policy would be hindered and restricted by the free trade agreement.
Supply
Furthermore, as we pointed out, we eliminated entirely under the free trade agreement the right of Canada to impose export taxes which would be one way again of ensuring that we would have the right, in terms of our natural resources, to require it to be used in Canada and if it was to be exported that we could put a tax on it to at least get a proper benefit from it. That right, of course, was again surrendered. It is one of the reasons why it is essential that the free trade agreement be renegotiated, that we expunge those articles from any kind of trade agreement because, once again, it puts Canada in a position of subservience and it puts Canada in a position of losing control over its valuable resource.
We think of the importance of water to every region of this country; to our cities, to our agricultural areas, to our sports and tourism. It will become one of the great Canadian resources in the future if we can retain control. Under the free trade agreement that is a doubtful proposition which goes back to the fundamental position of our party: the need to renegotiate the agreement.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to take part in this debate today to talk about a motion put forward by a member of the NDP asking for immediate withdrawal from the FTA. I am pleased to see that even the Official Opposition now, after they had a meeting in Hull where the business people came in and seemed to have a little chat with them, are supportive of the free trade agreement, maybe have it altered and changed, but certainly they are not talking the rhetoric they did in the last election of the immediate abrogation of the free trade agreement. Certainly we are on the same side as far as maintaining the free trade agreement. It is amazing how times have changed and we are pleased about that.
I think though the most important thing to understand about the motion before us today is that it represents a prescription that would lead to the isolation of Canada from its international trading partner. It springs this motion from a policy that is very shortsighted, and shortsighted in the extreme, in that it represents really a lack of understanding of economic and international trade realities.
Instead, rather than dwelling on the motion and the aspects of it, I would like to dwell upon and devote my time today to an explanation of how I feel Canada's vital interests are served by the government's decision to participate in a North American free trade negotiation. I

March 13, 1992
Supply
would also like, for the benefit of my hon. colleagues across the way, to outline some of the anticipated benefits that would flow from a successful conclusion of a NAFTA agreement.
I also want to show, with respect to this last point in particular, how a successful conclusion of the NAFTA will result in a positive contribution to the ability of Mexico and its brave peoples to fully launch itself on the road to economic prosperity and the democratic development that they so much desire.
In the last 40 years, international trade and economic environment has evolved to the point where the isolationist and mercantilist policies of old have been discredited, as we all know. We are in a global economy. Governments, and indeed entire political systems, have come to the realization that it makes no more sense to throw up barriers between countries than it is to throw up barriers between parts of a single city or a county. We have seen what gifts history has brought to those countries that have put up barriers around them, and we all know too well what has happened to their economies.
Global interdependence makes each of us dependent upon each other now. It is a structure that most fully rewards the competitive advantages of nations. We have seen in decades past what happens in a world where economic security will lead to political and military insecurity.
The North American free trade negotiation is but one element of the government's over-all trade and competitiveness strategy, which is designed to ensure the future prosperity for Canada and all Canadians. That strategy also includes action plans designed to deal with the complex issues being discussed in the Uruguay round of the multilateral trade negotiations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Both were preceded by the successful negotiation of the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement, which has given Canada increased access, as I especially noted earlier, to the companies in my constituency. It has given them more access and lower tariffs and more competitive advantage in the U.S. marketplace.
The proposition that Canada is part of the global economic reality seems to be one that is denied by certain members from across the aisle, and it certainly is
denied by the motion we have before us today. We on this side of the aisle understand that Canada has succeeded in building a modem post-industrial society, where fully a third of our economic prosperity depends on international trade.
My hon. colleagues would be surprised, undoubtedly, to learn that Canadian exports account for over three million jobs in Canada today. With so many jobs on the line, it is certainly sad, indeed, that we are debating a motion that would, if enacted, result in Canada giving up our preferred access to the U.S. market and to turn away from negotiations with one of the most dynamic economies to emerge in all of Latin America.
However, simply being in the game is clearly not enough. The government and the private sector, including the labour movement, must all work together to ensure that Canadian workers are given the tools necessary to win in this competitive situation we are in. For that we must equip ourselves so that we can play and beat the best in the global arena we are all in.
The government understands that to win, Canada must improve the competitive position of individual business enterprises as much as we must improve our competitive position as a nation. My colleague, the Minister for International Trade and the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology, has launched a competitive investigation, a competitive consultation across the country so that we can look at the five main areas of concentration of competitiveness.
The government understands that learning and education must be a lifelong commitment that serves not only to enrich our lives individually, but also a commodity that ensures the ability of Canadians to respond to future economic challenges and secure long-term, high wage jobs.
Canadian companies need to be given the flexibility so they can successfully adapt to changing market signals. On the production side they must become adept at translating international scientific research and technology into products that can be sold in markets secured by trade agreements.
We need to ensure that innovative Canadian companies have access to equally innovative financial and investment tools and strategies that are needed to
March 13, 1992

support an outward-looking growth-oriented economy able to successfully compete in the global marketplace.
On the home front, our international efforts must be complemented by a more active dismantling of those domestic barriers that inhibit a more competitive and integrated Canadian market.
The fifth major element of the competitive study and competitive rebirth must be that of ensuring that Canada retains its ability to participate in a meaningful way in the foreign markets. This can only be ensured by a strategic approach to international trade negotiations such as that followed by the government in its successful negotiations with the FTA, the Uruguay round and NAFTA.
The presenter of the motion before us today does not seem to understand that trade within North America is already at a level of some $250 billion annually in American dollars. Negotiation of a North American free trade agreement is a vote of confidence by the three countries in the anticipated future of that trade.
Seldom have trade negotiations proceeded on such a solid foundation as that provided by Canada, the U.S. and Mexico. I have already noted that the three-way trade is approximately $250 billion American in trade. To that fact I may note that the combined gross domestic product of the three parties is in excess of $6 trillion U.S. If you are looking for a market in which to develop, produce and sell your goods, you would certainly have a difficult time finding a better one and a more expansive one in the world than the North American market.
The North American market will afford Canadian companies greater opportunities to forge additional economies of scale and production efficiency. On a foundation of enhanced competitiveness, they will be able to increase the capacity of their production as the barriers to trade are gradually phased out.
When considering the need for Canada to be an active participant in NAFTA negotiations, I would ask members to reflect on the fact that Mexico, after the United States, is our largest trading partner in the western hemisphere. As I said, a successful NAFTA negotiation will open up the Mexican market, which itself is poised for expansion. While trade between Canada and Mexico is relatively small now, accounting for some $2.2 billion
Supply
in two-way trade, a NAFTA will provide an opportunity for us to expand upon that lucrative market for Canadian companies.
In the first instance, Canada seeks to negotiate the gradual removal of Mexican tariffs and other import barriers that currently block Canadian exporters of goods and services from reaching their full potential. The Mexican market is currently 85 million strong and is growing with each passing year. As the economy of Mexico grows, so will the purchasing power of its citizens. Mexico is an economy in transition and a successful NAFTA will help to position Canada to take advantage of the growing commercial opportunities that are presenting themselves in that country.
Also of great importance is the need for Canada to preserve its place as a preferred location for investment, both foreign and domestic. By offering investors access to not only the Canadian market, but also to those markets in the U.S. and Mexico, Canada will help to maintain our inherent attractiveness as a place to do business. A North American free trade agreement will guarantee that no matter where a company chooses to build its plants, it will have access to all three countries, and artificial trade barriers will not be a determining factor as they make those decisions.
I have also heard the minister say that Canada has a chance to build upon the achievements of the FTA where such improvements are of benefit to Canada. This was noted before, but now the Liberal Party seems to be saying yes, we are against the motion today; we want the FTA to remain but we want to improve upon it. Well, we have that opportunity in the NAFTA negotiations to explore the possibility of mutually beneficial improvements to the FTA. For example, maritime shipping could be one area that we certainly would look at. Also, content of cars in the agreement could be looked at.
A successful NAFTA would provide Canadian firms with greater access to the lower-cost production inputs that are necessary if we are to remain competitive with the dynamic economies of Europe and the Pacific Rim that we are competing with. The ability under the agreement to source high-quality products, high-quality components from, say, Mexico by our Canadian component assemblers could be a definite advantage to the competitiveness of our companies.

March 13, 1992
Supply
Following on the lead established by the FTA and carried forth in the MTN, Canada seeks, in the NAFTA, a trade dispute settlement procedure that is rapid, that follows clear and fair rules, and that is cost effective and accessible to the Canadian business sector. Trade disagreements, while they only involve a small percentage of the total trade between nations, can develop into major irritants if countries do not have at their disposal a fair and impartial method of settlement. As we know, before the FTA, we did not have one.
As was noted earlier by my colleague opposite from Winnipeg, who said, "Well, the dispute settlement mechanism is not any good", we did not have anything before. Yes, maybe we can end up with an even better one. Certainly we have taken it out of the political realm. As you know, the U.S. political scene is special interest driven, and it was special interest politically driven in the decisions that we were getting through the U.S. commerce department, and there was no other place to go. Now we have an impartial tribunal dispute settlement mechanism that certainly has proven already, in a couple of instances, to be beneficial to Canada.
Before closing, I would like to lend my support to one of the themes raised by the Prime Minister in Question Period some few days ago. In answer to a question, the Prime Minister noted that the government felt strongly that the NAFTA afforded Mexico the opportunity to further its development goals. Mexico's President Salinas has said, on more than one occasion, that Mexico would prefer to reach its development goals through trade rather than through foreign aid.
Again, I am surprised at the NDP putting together such a motion. It is for helping the down-trodden and for people who need help and helping them. Here is an opportunity to help many people in the country of Mexico to raise themselves up economically through a free trade agreement on a North American basis. I am very surprised that it would not be supportive of that, to help them raise themselves economically.
In ending, I would like to say that I have, in this debate, attempted to explain some of the benefits that will come to Canada as a consequence of our participation in the North American free trade negotiations. I would hope that all members of the House would come to an understanding that Canada's future lies in securing a prosperous place on the stage of international trade.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I just want to congratulate my colleague for the rather sound and principled speech that he has put forward on this important question that was placed before the House.
I also want to congratulate him on his reluctance to move too deeply into some of the comments that we heard from the previous two speakers. It shows great control on his part, control that I am not at all sure that I have available.
I have heard the comment again about water. My goodness, how many times must we go around that issue? They tried it in the election of 1988 and it did not work, and it is not going to work now.
Then we had the old chestnut again raised about medical costs being somehow challengeable under the FTA. Everybody knows that is not so. You cannot challenge a universal program available to all under that. Even if you could, Madam Speaker, the costs rung up by our American colleagues in most of their major industries for health insurance is far, far more expensive and therefore challengeable than costs to Canadian corporations.
The member opposite should know that and get off this business of once again trying to frighten those people in Canada who need that kind of protection, particularly the seniors. I find it almost despicable that we are into this again.
I congratulate my colleague for not being quite as vigorous on this matter as I am.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do not know if there was a question there from my colleague, but there certainly was a comment. I would like to comment on his comment.
I was reluctant to even respond to this business of water. I am a little surprised because I have the feeling that the members of the Official Opposition have altered their position because of a conference they had over in Hull some time ago. Perhaps some people told them they were a little off base. The free trade agreement is important and it should be maintained. Now they are
March 13, 1992

saying: "Yes, but we want to improve upon it". That is well enough said.
But to go back and start talking about water or including the old fear-mongering they tried in the last election, I would suggest that they not continue with that at all. I do not think it goes over well with the Canadian public today. I would suggest that they should stay way from that.
We certainly welcome their support of the free trade agreement. There should be a free trade agreement. Also the member from Winnipeg mentioned with some positiveness the NAFTA. Wow, I guess the numbers must not have been in his favour at the meeting in Hull. It looks like they are coming of age and understanding. When one is the government one gets to understand it to a greater extent. They must have had a few people bring them on side at their little session in Hull. This is pleasing and we are pleased to have their support.
They have some great ideas and suggestions on how to improve the North American free trade agreement. That is great but do not use fear-mongering. I do not think it is fair that Canadians be subjected to that kind of thing. Water never has been and never will be part of a free trade agreement between Canada and the United States. That is known by practically everybody, other than those who want to use fear-mongering.
I appreciate the opportunity to respond.

Madam Speaker, I was just listening at the tail end of the speech of the hon. member. I would just like to comment on the free trade agreement as such.
I believe when we were discussing the free trade agreement and Mr. Reisman was our negotiator, he was assuring us that there would be a period where there would be adjustments, otherwise we would be losing jobs.
The most important thing he forgot when he was negotiating was that our cost of production is much higher than in the United States. The cost of money is much higher because our interest rates are much higher and the rate of taxation is much higher than across the border. Therefore, how can we compete and have a free trade agreement on the same level if the cost of production is much higher here than in the United States?
Supply
Naturally we are seeing that industry is moving south because we are unable to compete. It is much more expensive to produce north of the border than south of the border.
Why did you support the agreement?
Somebody is asking: "Why did I support the agreement"? I did it because I was fooled. They fooled me. It is simple.
The whole country was fooled.

Another member just said the whole country was fooled. This is why I believe that we should have a second look at that agreement and take steps to correct those elements I just cited. It is impossible for a country to be competitive with another country where the cost of production is much higher. The cost of production is much higher in Canada than it is in the United States.
Now we are talking about a free trade agreement with Mexico. Imagine! What is going to happen to Canada? We will lose most of the industry and become suppliers of the raw materials for the United States and Mexico. I believe this is a deal that was negotiated in bad faith.
I saw the negotiator, Mr. Reisman, at noon in the parliamentary restaurant. I do not know what he is doing, but he should be called before the bar of this Parliament and asked questions. How did he make the deal? The Prime Minister should be called because he really sold out Canada to the United States.
We have to negotiate; we know that. We have to trade; we know that, but to do so, we should be protecting the interests of Canadians and we have not been doing that.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, hon. members should note countries like Japan and Germany. They probably have the highest wage rates in the world yet they compete with automobiles and they compete throughout the world. They have relative differences than other countries. It is one of a total balance sheet production efficiency side.
What are we going to do? Close all the borders up? Stay within ourselves, throw millions of people out of work? We have to be competitive. We have to compete in the world. We have to open up our borders and we have to learn to compete with our productivity and efficiency.

March 13, 1992
Supply
I was thinking earlier of the members opposite, rattling about the free trade agreement. As a government, they overspent for years and years and drove us into a debt situation that has made for increased taxation. That is one of the big reasons we have a problem with competitiveness that must be turned around. We have to get rid of this massive deficit, this situation that they put us in. They are rattling about a free trade agreement, about being competitive. They put this country in a position of indebtedness and it will take us years to get out of it. I am appalled at them coming forward with such arguments.
Members say we have to compete, that our industries have to be competitive, but they have to have somebody to compete against or otherwise we, as consumers, just keep on paying ever higher costs for things. We have done this for many, many years and we are fed up with that sort of stuff. We are not going to do that any more. Our companies have to be competitive. We have to compete and we can compete.
We do billions and billions of dollars of trade with the United States and we compete every day. Seventy per cent of the product from major corporations in my area goes to the United States. We can compete. We are looking at building a new major world scale ethylene plant in Sarnia. It can compete operationally with the gulf coast. It has an after tax problem that we have addressed in the budget and now hopefully Ontario will help us with it, but it is operational. We can compete so do not say we cannot. Dupont can compete, ICI can compete, Esso can compete, Cabot Carbon can compete, Ethyl can compete. They will all ship product into the U.S., our biggest market so do not tell me they cannot compete.
We are going to compete more and better and better as we look at how to help them in a competitive situation in our country.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to speak for the second time in two days on the subject of trade and free trade.
On Wednesday night, the House had an emergency debate on the disastrous effect the Canada-U.S. trade deal has on the softwood lumber industry. We heard members talk about job losses the Americans will force
on us. Members opposite tried to convince Canadians that we will receive a favourable decision from the binational panel.
However, the result is clear. The trade deal has not benefited Canada and has done serious damage to some very important industries.
As I said the other night, this government tried to convince Canadians that with the trade deal the Americans would become our partners in trade. There would be a glorious and prosperous future. The country would be more competitive and we would have guaranteed access to the United States market. Canada and the United States would work together. Sadly this is not the case.
Practically every trade action taken against Canada in the last number of years has been launched by the Americans. B.C. salmon and herring processing was challenged by the Americans. The U.S. challenged us over ice cream and yogurt. Our problems at the GATT over supply management are caused by Americans who wish to destroy our supply management system.
The subsidy war between the U.S. and Europe is killing our western grain farmers, as does the decision to put a duty on Canadian built Hondas and the softwood lumber tariff. With friends like that we do not need many enemies. The Americans will not look after our interests that is very clear. What we need is a government here in Ottawa that will protect Canadians. Three years after the deal let us look at the results.
There are over 1.4 million people in Canada looking for work. Today there are more food banks in Canada than there are McDonald's restaurants. Every day we hear about another plant closing, jobs moving south to the U.S., all this from a deal that was supposed to make us competitive.
A large reason for the failure of the trade deal was this government did not provide the adjustment programs it promised during the election campaign. It said it would not be possible to determine what job losses were caused by the deal. I say it would be easy to find which jobs were lost by the deal. Just count the Canadian companies that have moved to places like Buffalo, Seattle, Florida and Louisiana. Companies do not move because of the
March 13, 1992

weather, they move because they can make higher profits, because the cost of business is lower.
The federal government did not help the situation because it allowed Canadian interest rates to soar and the value of the dollar to climb, making exports less profitable. The Canadian food processing industry has been particularly hard hit by this trade deal. In order to have a prosperous food industry you need two things, protection for your producer and protection for your processor.
Before this deal Canada had both. Supply management allowed farmers in the dairy, egg and poultry sectors to earn a decent return on their investment while ensuring a secure a supply to customers and industry at a reasonable price. As well with some import duties our food processors were able to make a fair return on their investment while providing jobs for Canadians.
Now, with the deal, the protection for our food processors has been removed and what do we see? Something like 80 Canadian food processors have closed up shop and moved to the U.S., throwing thousands of Canadians out of work.
What the Americans could not get through the trade deal they are trying to get from the GATT by challenging our supply management. It is a small miracle that there is any food industry left in Canada at all.
The Liberal Party has always believed in a competitive and prosperous Canada. With co-operation between business and labour and the right policies from government, Canada can provide a prosperous future for our children.
New Democrats refuse to recognize the reality that the U.S. is our largest trading partner and that we should work toward a favourable trading arrangement with the Americans.
The government should seek to improve the trade deal with the U.S. Sadly we know this government is unwilling or unable to stand up fqr Canadian interests. That is why after the next election a Liberal government will stand up for Canada in renegotiating the deal and if we cannot reach a favourable agreement then we will invoke the six month withdrawal clause.
Supply
It would be foolish to slam the door shut on our largest trading partner without first seeking to solve our problems. Heavy dependence on one partner is never wise, but it will take time before we can develop markets to move into.
The government wants Canada locked into a deal with the American giant without looking at the consequences. The New Democrats want us to abandon $200 billion in trade. That is not possible.
What is possible is the Liberal position of negotiating a better deal with the United States and through multilateral agreements expand our trade options.
We cannot go blindly into the future. We must develop a balanced approach that favours Canadian interests and Canadian jobs.
Madam Speaker, I appreciate the comments that the hon. member made-

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Yes, they were excellent.

In fact they were excellent from his perspective. They were very well delivered and I compliment him on it.
The question I would really have is that he talked about a better deal, that the Liberal Party would negotiate improvements to the deal. But as I listened to his speech, I did not hear him comment about what those improvements were.
Rather than leave it up to the electorate to elect the hon. member's party and after the fact say: "There, now we are elected and we have dotted that i which was not dotted before, that makes it a better deal," I would be curious if the member could give me three or four examples of very clear things that he thinks ought to be improved upon.

Madam Speaker, I thank my hon. colleague from across the way. There are a number of things. We certainly have to find out exactly what is going on. Here we are involved in a trade deal with a nation that is ten times our size and we have not established yet what a subsidy is.
There are many things that we have to do just to find out exactly where we are.

March 13, 1992
Supply
I also think we have to look at things that happened for example in the fishing industry, in the herring and salmon industry on the west coast.
The Americans were always striving to have a certain percentage of the fish to process, but through the trade deal we did not permit this. The ink was hardly dry on the deal when the Americans applied through GATT. I would be very surprised if the government was not aware that they would be able to obtain this through GATT. They were able to obtain the fish through GATT and because we have the trade deal we were not able to put an export tax on the fish.
Unfortunately, now the Americans have the right to a certain percentage of our salmon and herring on the west coast. It is very unfortunate because we lose a lot of jobs, jobs that are badly needed on the west coast.
On the east coast in the lobster industry, it was in 1990 when the American government decided that they were going to increase the size of the lobster. We can always go to this great dispute settlement mechanism, but from what I understand it only decides whether the law of the importing nation was properly applied.
For an exporting nation where, in the name of God, does that leave us? We are an exporting nation and the Americans decide we are not going to ship the fish in. They decide possibly we are not going to ship potatoes in.
The problem I see with the trade deal is that the Americans do all the deciding and we, as an exporting nation, need to have some say in the process. As far as I can see, we have very little say.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is a great pleasure today to debate this supply motion.
I must tell you that I do not agree with the New Democrats' motion, and I challenge them to rise right away and contradict me when I say that this motion is definitely not in Canadians' interest. You will note, Madam Speaker, that they did not even reply. But I want to tell you that I would not want the government opposite to start thinking that I am about to praise it either, because that will not happen.
Now that we have established that, let us read carefully what those fine people to the far left want us to do.
They want us to say that in the opinion of this House, Canada should withdraw from the negotiations concerning the North American free trade agreement. Withdraw. Don't want to talk about it; don't want to even see what the Americans are going to do to us when we are not there. They prefer that we not be there.
Okay, maybe by not being there we will not know how bad things are, and therefore what we do not know will not hurt us, according to the NDP.
We should also give notice of withdrawal from the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement and pursue a global strategy not based on making the planet an unfettered playground for the multinational corporate elite.
Now that last sentence is a little catchy. But I would like to remind the House what it is that happens when New Democrats propose motions that are not thought of very seriously.
I will give you an example to make my point. You will remember that some weeks ago we had a New Democratic motion on GATT. Well, someone sat behind the word processor at the great NDP nirvana someplace in this building and wrote a press release.
They announced that the NDP were proposing a motion that the government refuse to sign the GATT. I have a copy of it right here, it is dated February 7 and it was supposed to be in regard to the February 12 opposition day.
The NDP released a few copies of this around and some people did not like it. Actually, many of their supporters did not like it, particularly in western Canada. So they had to run around pulling back the copies of the press release already issued because they had embarrassed themselves, that Canada should not be part of the GATT.
Maybe we should move Canada to another planet, according to the NDP. They live on the moon anyway, most of them are Looney Tunes, so they want us to move someplace else.
March 13, 1992

When the motion did appear in the House, it said "that this party calls on the government to support unequivocally a GATT accord that would-" and then it gives all those fine things that a GATT accord would do. It is not exactly the same. You see what happens? A press release, some people talked to the NDP, they smarten up, and then the final draft.
Do you know what happened today? No one proofread the motion. That is what happened. And, because no one proof-read the motion, we have a motion here that calls on Canada to run away from the North American negotiations. For all I know, the deal might be a bad deal, but how will we know unless we are there?
Then also, that we should pull out of the free trade agreement.

Madam Speaker, we know that in my riding, we lost many factories because the free trade agreement was badly negotiated. But I ask the New Democrats this: What factory in my riding will reopen if the free trade agreement is cancelled? That is a good question! I know of none, not one. Of course the few industries that may have gained would also lose with that. So we would have lost those that we had already lost and we would lose the small gains made since then. We would be losers all around. That is the New Democrats' position.
Now we have the position of the government opposite, which signs anything that the President of the United States shows them. That is the other side of the story. So here we have a free trade agreement that was signed late in 1988, if I recall. This free trade agreement was signed in a building in Washington, apparently over a meal of Kentucky fried chicken, at three o'clock in the morning by the then Minister of Finance, who had come to Simon Reisman's rescue. Despite all his finesse, Mr. Reisman had managed to bungle the whole deal.
So we have this badly negotiated agreement which contains no definition of subsidies and includes a regulatory mechanism that of course binds Canada but not the United States, a partner ten times as big as the other, with nothing to offset this disadvantage. Finally, it contains nothing to set the value of the respective
Supply
currencies, which means that as our dollar rises, we can lose as much as if a previously existing tariff was reduced.
Everything I mentioned, Madam Speaker, is what the government opposite gave us. The members on the left, the far left, want to undo what has been done without going back to what existed before, because that is impossible, and want to withdraw from the negotiations as well.

It could very well be that when the so-called NAFTA agreement is finished, we will not like it either. It could very well be that the government will not even like it, for all I know, although the Americans like it. Anyway, I will give them the benefit of the doubt for the moment. Not much of it, but some.
The point is, how do we know all that unless we are there at the table negotiating? How do we know that the Americans will not give away what we have when we are not there? How do we know that they will not establish policies between each other that will be a nuisance to us, unless we are there? We do not know that. That is why this motion should have been proof-read. That is why someone at the headquarters of whoever wrote this thing on the back of an envelope last night should have reread it before they put it on the word processor. That is why this is wrong.
That does not mean that we should be congratulating the government.

As I said earlier, this government has not protected the Canadian economy as it could have.

If I have a few minutes left, I would like to read an excerpt from a letter by a constituent, Mr. William Howieson, who sent a letter to The Ottawa Citizen responding to an editorial they had written on farming. Because of the very limited time, here is what he said, in part. He was comparing Canadian farmers to U.S. farmers. He said: "The 1990 New York business summary of 395 farms reveals that the total cost to produce 100 pounds of milk in the U.S. was $15.27. The comparable figure in the 1990 Ontario Farm Accounting Project of

March 13, 1992
