204 farms was $15.32." In other words, there is a 5 cent difference out of $15.
Some members across the way who do not support supply management-not all; by and large the government does-and some so-called consumer advocacy groups are not aware that our farmers here in Canada are every bit as efficient as those on the American side. What is different is the subsidy afforded to both groups.

The hon. member for Algoma raised the point this morning in Oral Question Period in the House of Commons when he told us about a study done in the United States which reported the thousands and thousands of dollars in subsidies to American producers at the same time as those people claim to want to compete with us on an equal footing or "level playing field".
There is nothing equal, Madam Speaker, when Canadian farmers compete with the U.S. treasury. There is nothing equal about that.

In conclusion, I want to tell Canadians that what we need is neither the folks across the way nor the extremists, who are left with their ridiculous concoctions that they brought to the House today. What we need is something more reasonable, like a Liberal government.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise and participate in this veiy important resolution.
There are, I guess, three points of view being expressed in general. One is from that group that the previous speaker describes as, if I can quote him correctly, Looney Tunes, or something on that basis. I am not sure I necessarily share the name, but I think it adequately reflects a view. The second is from those across the way. The third, of course, is from those on the government side.
Before I give some comments on that, I have a slight quiz for you. I do not know if you would like to answer this, but let me give you a few quotes and we will see if you can answer. If you cannot, I will be glad to provide the answer for you.
Who do you think said: "We need lower, not higher trade barriers here and around the word if we are to
build efficient manufacturing industries and increase our productivity?" Who do you think said: "Not only could Canada benefit considerably from freer international trade, it is incorrect to claim that trade liberalization would destroy certain Canadian industries." Finally, who do you think said: "He isn't moved by the insecurity these issues raise for affected workers. I want these people to be afraid of losing their jobs. It's the best motivation in the world."
I realize it is going to take some considerable thought as to who said all those great words. It would be hard to identify him with anything he is saying today, but it is the actual Leader of the Opposition today who made those comments. In fact, they are quoted in Le Soleil, July 15, 1978 and in Hansard on October 20. The questions are there. They are very clear. They are his.
I do not think I heard any of that comment today from members opposite, but I thought I would share them with you, because they obviously have some influence. Should they ever form a government, heaven forbid, they will come back and say: "Yes, but you know what I've been saying all along. What I said during the election campaign is not really what we were going to implement. Just look at my speeches prior to the election." I think it had something to do with that back in the mid-seventies when they campaigned against wage and price controls, and after the election, they said: "Look what we said before. Don't count that." They campaigned on 18 cents a gallon and then afterwards said: "Forget what we said during the election. Look at what we said other times."
I thought I would share that with you. I am sure it is of benefit.
Let me give you more recent information. I think there are some interesting articles. In yesterday's Globe and Mail, in an article written by Peter Cook, there are a couple of paragraphs I would like to relate to you. Peter Cook said:
The anti-free traders are wrong. But, in the absence of an alternative and in their willingness to misapply every fact and statistic, they have a great capacity to deceive. It is now routinely stated that all the jobs lost in a cyclical recession have been lost "under" or "since" free trade.
I carry on. It says:
A new study by WEFA Canada of Toronto entitled "Why has Canada's economy performed so poorly?" sets the argument in its right context, explodes the free-trade myth, properly takes Ottawa and the provinces to task for very fundamental policy mistakes and
March 13, 1992

deserves to be better circulated and read than the betrayal-of-Canada
drivel put out by the anti-free traders.
I thought I would share that with you. There are some people out there in the world who say, particularly here in Canada, yes, we've got some problems and yes, governments have made some mistakes, both federally and provincially. I would have loved to see the dollar stay at 84 or 85 cents rather than go all the way to 89 cents, and yes, that would have been much easier if we had not had the deficit remain in the $30 billion range during the last six or seven years. I understand that, but the fact of the matter is we are there and we have to deal with those issues.
But to then listen to colleagues opposite talk about the devastation that has been racked on the industry of Canada and our exports, I should point out some other useful numbers, and I am sure you are writing these down with great anticipation because they are going to be useful in any speeches you might give as well.
Our exports to the United States in 1988 were $102 billion. In 1989 they were $105 billion. I realize that is about a 3 per cent increase and that is the first year of the free trade agreement. Certainly that does not sound like any disaster to anything. It does not sound like boom times either if you only increase exports 3 per cent, but it is certainly very positive.
In 1990 we went from $105 billion to $110 billion in exports. Again, that is about a 5 per cent increase, but no great boom times. Again, it is a positive number. Unfortunately the numbers are not fully finalized for 1991, but I acknowledge that it looks like they are going to come in at about $107 billion, which is down some $3 billion from the year before. That is not great, but that is certainly no disaster. That is still well in excess of what it was in 1988 prior to the free trade agreement.
When you look at where we saw the improvements, I think that is the more interesting number, because between 1988 and 1990, our sales went up in things that were technology, in things that were manufacturing. Things like nuclear reactors, boilers, machinery, and mechanical appliances were up 6.7 per cent. Electrical machinery, equipment parts thereof, sound recorders and reproducers, television image and sound recorders and reproducers, and parts and accessories of such articles were up 63 per cent. It is certainly a nice number. Plastics and articles thereof were up 16.5 per cent; furniture, bedding, mattresses, mattress support, cush-
Supply
ions and similar stuff, furnishings, lamps and lighting fixtures, not elsewhere specified, a 14.5 per cent increase; aircraft, spacecraft and parts thereof, a 53 per cent increase; rubber and articles thereof, a 16.8 per cent increase.
Those are all good things. What are we hiding our heads for? I am rather proud of those statistics, and that is why I shared them with you. I think when you look at some of these items that are being mentioned across the way, they talk about how bad things are and they seem to want to ignore that.
Let me give you some examples, because those are general numbers. You hear stories about all these major companies that are doing poorly. Well, maybe they are, but let me give you an example of some that may give you a different perspective.
These are all located in my riding, and I thought I would bring it down to that perspective because it is easy to take the companies in the headlines, the ones that announce their $100 million expansion or announce their closing; they are easy to identify. Here is one, a company called All Temp. It is a small business, privately owned. It employs 35 people, and it really has not changed since 1988, so they indicate. Sales volume is up. It is up considerably. It distributes motors, refrigeration parts, things of that nature. Its prices are in fact lower, and some of that is because of the actual reductions that took place in duty.
More importantly, it found that there has been a reduction in the competition from the Far East, the Orient, because it is now able to source more of their products, either in Canada or the United States, and having eliminated the duty, it is in fact more competitive against those companies who use far eastern parts. That is why its business has gone up.
It has also found that some of its suppliers have been able to source some of their production now in Mexico, further reducing their cost of the parts, which in fact has made North America benefit because of the reduced over-all cost to the whole system versus that of the Far East.
So there is a company that has clearly benefited by the free trade agreement, and it says so very clearly.
Another company in my riding is Sollas Canada from Pickering. It was recently purchased by Canadian investors from its Dutch parent. It is a small company. It is a

Supply
distributor and manufacturer of various plastic banding and packaging equipment. Since free trade was implemented, the company has expanded from three employees to 15 employees. It has moved into a new facility four times as large as what it had before. Its U.S. customer base has grown considerably. Prior to 1989, it had absolutely no U.S. customers. Today, approximately 50 per cent of its customer base is U.S. oriented. What was its forecast for 1992? A great year, the best year it has ever had.
Another company is Timbrem Industries, a company in Ajax, privately owned. It manufactures heavy duty rubber-assisted suspension for trucks, a very unique product made in Ajax. It exports 75 per cent of its output to the United States; 100 per cent of its raw material is Canadian. It supports the deal with the United States, and in fact its sales volume has increased significantly over the three-year period, on an average of about 20 per cent, and it has similar forecasts for 1992. In fact, if it is convinced into the year that the year is progressing as it thought it would, it will in fact proceed with an expansion that it has on its drawing board. Now, it is not employing a lot more people, only three, but it did employ 15 to start; it now has 18. That is positive.
There are others. We talk about how Canadian food processors cannot compete. Is it not interesting that in fact the supplier of the fresh meat and so on to the House of Commons is a constituent of mine. It was recently a new company. It was established in 1989. The sales volume in 1991 was up 50 per cent over 1989.
A larger company this time, GE Canada opened a plant in my riding. GE Silicones opened a plant 70,000 square feet in size. It was talking about 1991 being the biggest year in the history of the company. It has the world mandate on behalf of GE to supply silicones to all of their operations world-wide. Its major customer is of course the United States. It is that volume that it gets out of the United States and in fact Canada that enables it to be competitive world-wide.
As I say, GE Canada just opened this new plant, but not only did it open the new plant, it had so many orders that it could not shut down the old plant when planned because the capacity of both plants was needed to fill the order backlog. That company is very supportive of the free trade agreement and it is forecasting a banner year in 1992.
Those are some examples of companies that are doing well and there are others, but what I get from the motion is that members of the NDP would walk away from all of that, would walk away from the success stories, from the whole international trade relationship that we have with the United States, the possible relationship that we have with Mexico. They criticize the international companies that create a lot of employment.
Well, what would we fall back on? I guess I can go back to my experience prior to my election. I was involved in the steel business and we exported extensively to the United States.


That company is a supporter of the free trade agreement. It talks about the benefits in that industry which have really been benefits to the consumer. It has been able to comment that because of the competition that exists in the marketplace on processed food, and it is a meat processor, in fact the price has been much more stable.
I know that on this side of the House we would not too often, but on the other side, since those members do not usually have a lot to do in the summer, they would have their barbecues where they serve a lot of steaks. They would know that in the summertime the price of steak used to go up because it was barbecue season. Well no more. There has been real price stability in that product line.
What did we have in the United States? We had government agencies working with the President and working with the Congress of the United States putting controls through such artificial trade barriers as a thing called a trigger price mechanism. That is, if steel was shipped below a certain price, all of a sudden it was subject to countervail action and duties and the matter would be dragged through the courts.
All of those actions were taken in the United States, not to get Canada, but were taken to get other countries in the world that were dumping their steel into the U.S. market holus-bolus. But the fact of the matter was that Canada was included.
We were innocent of all of that nonsense, but we were included because there was no mechanism in the U.S. system to prevent Canada from being included. It was

March 13, 1992

simply that when the U.S. announced a duty package all countries in the world were affected.
Prior to the trigger price mechanism, the U.S. implemented various artificial quotas on the countries that were accepted, that they were going to have 3 per cent of their market and they could ship all they want at whatever price they wanted, as long as they did not exceed 3 per cent.
Canada got caught on that. Yet we were not the problem. At least the free trade agreement prevents that from happening.
The NDP would love us to go back to that old kind of system where we get swept in on all these trade disputes, whether we are a party, whether we are guilty or whether we are innocent.
We are dragged in simply because members of the NDP would love us to chuck the free trade agreement. Not only would they have us chuck it, what amazes me is that they even have the gall to bring forward this resolution.
When I look at who the NDP members of Parliament purport to represent, in my neighbouring constituency, the constituency of Oshawa, there is a company called General Motors. I will bet it fits the description of the very international companies that they are criticizing for their investments in Canada.
I will bet you the member for Oshawa has not had the guts to go back to Oshawa and say: "GM get out of Oshawa. Go away. We do not want your investment. We do not want your jobs." I wonder if the various members from Windsor have gone back and said: "You know, these international corporations that have the freedom to simply move from this area to that area of the world, care less"-they have not chased them out of Windsor. They have not said: "We don't want them in Windsor." Of course they do not say that because these people are good employers.
Simply being a large international corporation does not make it a bandit. It does not make it an irresponsible citizen of the world. There are some tremendously large corporations that in fact are very responsible.
In my riding there is Du Pont Canada that has lots of international affiliations. Du Pont is a very responsible
Supply
company and before it was mandated by governments it was dealing with the whole issue of ozone within its environmental package.
I can comfortably say that as it relates to the environment, Du Pont was in fact providing leadership on the issue. Was it going fast enough? We can always debate whether it was or was not. But the fact of the matter is it started before governments started, not just the Government of Canada, I would say governments around the world.
Du Pont was on its way to trying to rectify some of the environmental problems that it knew its products were causing. But it was fine to simply criticize Du Pont. It is we Canadians, Americans and others in other parts of the world who wanted Du Pont's products, and it was happy to provide them. Once it was aware of the problem, of course it tried to rectify it.
So the NDP say: "Walk away from these trade agreements. Walk away from the FTA, and don't get involved in the North American free trade agreement".
I will acknowledge that the agreement is a very ambitious undertaking. And the agreement is being negotiated, I would say at a timely moment.
The nations of the world are struggling to compete, and we hear this all the time through multilateral negotiations aimed at creating a more level playing field for exporters. That is part of this whole GATT negotiation process that is under way in the world.
As a country, Canada is certainly trade dependent. I do not think there would be anyone on any side of this House who would debate the importance of trade to Canada. If trade is important to us, then open markets on a global basis can only benefit us.
While Canada ranks eighth in the world in exports of goods and twelfth in the exports of services, there is no doubt that our future prosperity is highly dependent upon a successful track record.
What I would say to you is that it is not playgrounds that we are talking about, which is part of the NDP resolution; it is three million jobs in Canada which are dependent upon exports. Three million jobs are on the line if we simply abandon any attempt to get involved in very successful trading negotiations.

March 13, 1992
Supply
The North American free trade agreement negotiations constitute one step in that direction. To be competitive in the world our industry must successfully compete in North America.
A North American agreement would benefit the wide range of export-oriented Canadian goods and services producers provide. The NDP motion basically says that if we get out of the FTA, if we get out of the North American free trade agreement, presuming they would want to stay in GATT, we would be left as one country negotiating with 108 others to have everybody lower their barriers. At least history has those barriers coming down.
But what members of the NDP do not really comment on is that while those barriers are coming down, there are some countries in the world where the barriers are coming down even quicker. One needs only look at Europe where in a sense, a free trade agreement has been set up among the 12 European nations, basically eliminating all barriers to trade.
We have the same happening in the Pacific Rim where countries are very quickly dropping their barriers to trade. We have the same thing happening in discussions in South America among some of the countries.
Why would we as a country want to stand on our own and try to get into all those islands of trade liberalization and have to jump hurdles, when in fact we have the potential through the North American free trade agreement of dealing with a market of some 380 million people? It would be the largest market in the world covered under an agreement. That can only benefit Canada.
I talked about the company that has imports from Mexico, and is working with the U.S. and Canadian suppliers. It is successful.
So I suggest that there is no doubt in my mind that there are some clear benefits to being involved in the North American free trade agreement. Of course, until the agreement is really finalized it is hard to say if it is a good deal or a bad deal.
I am not going to stand up and say it is a great deal. I do not know what the deal is. But I think the intent is that we should be there, we should be negotiating, we should be protecting Canada and that is why I am happy to speak today in favour of Canada being exactly where we are right now.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to make a brief comment and then put two questions to the member.
I want to say what an important debate this has been today. It is probably a forerunner of the election to come. The only party in the country that is fighting for Canadians is in this House. New Democrats are fighting for Canadians who are losing their jobs because of Canada-U.S. free trade. They will likely in the future suffer even greater job losses because of North American free trade.
Clearly the debate today showed that those people in the New Democratic Party stand up for the working people of Canada and the Conservatives on the other side support free trade all the way. We are not sure what the position of the Liberals is. That is nothing unusual either. We will all have to deal with that in the election to come.
I have some questions for the member. First, we would know with regard to the North American free trade agreement that elected officials from all sides in both the Mexico and United States have had an opportunity, I understand, under security to go in and to look at the current draft agreement between Canada, the United States and Mexico, the North American free trade agreement. I would be interested in knowing if he has seen such an agreement from his minister, the Minister for International Trade?
Second, is he aware if any members of cabinet or on his side have seen that agreement?
Third, would he agree that sharing the information in the North American free trade agreement might go some distance to quelling some of the concerns of a lot of people about that agreement? Would he support that kind of openness that is apparently allowed in Mexico and the United States?
If we are to accept his argument that every single job loss could not be attributed to the Canada-U.S. free trade deal-of course many things happen in an economy-at the same time I am sure the member would agree that every single job created in the country since the Canada-U.S. free trade could not be attributed to the Canada-U.S. free trade.
March 13, 1992

Fourth, can he tell the House if he is aware if the government maintains any kind of list that on the one side he can attribute job gain to the Canada-U.S. free trade agreement and where he can rightfully attribute job loss due to businesses moving perhaps to the United States under the Canada-U.S. free trade? If he is aware of that, can he tell this House and does he think that information should be made available to Parliament? If it is not available, is that not something this government should be doing if it is so proud of the Canada-U.S. free trade so that it can try to prove its point?

Madam Speaker, first I will talk about the North American free trade agreement. No, I have not seen the draft that he has asked for. I do not know which of the cabinet has seen it. To be fair, I have not gone and asked each one of them. Nor have I seen a press release that has indicated who has seen it. However I have every confidence that all of those involved in the North American free trade agreement have seen it, whether it be the Secretary of State for External Affairs or the Minister for International Trade. I think that is certainly appropriate.
Does the member believe we should release it to the House and to the public? He has indicated that it is available in Mexico. If he thinks it is important that he see it, I suppose he should call his friends in Mexico which the member from Spadina indicated he had down there. I am sure they would be happy to share it with him. I do not think at this point in the negotiating stage that we need to necessarily release those documents in public. It is not standard practice.
The second item relates to job loss. The member is absolutely right. There are businesses closing. There are businesses opening. Those are functions of the economy. Those are functions of all kinds of factors within the economy, whether they be poor management, whether they be international trade competition, or whether it be simply a drying up of a market. For example, there is not a great demand any more for wringer washers out there. People want automatic washers. Those things are natural in the market.
I have seen a list of extensive new investment decisions in Canada. I do not know if they are simply related to the free trade agreement directly or whether it is because those people have decided Canada is an absolutely great place in which to invest because we have a good Conservative government and good economic policies.

Part of those policies are in fact the free trade agreement with the United States.

Madam Speaker, I want to put this on the record. I would like to correct the member from the New Democratic Party.
Most Canadians know where the Liberal Party has stood on the free trade agreement. People will never forget that during the last campaign that the member of Parliament, our then leader, the hon. member for Vancouver Quadra debated clearly and won the confidence of Canadians on his debating skills when it came to free trade.
Regretfully the Business Council on National Issues and other associations bought full page ads in most of the major dailies saying that some of the things that our then leader said about free trade were not accurate. Those full page ads probably had more to do with this government regaining power than anything else I know of.
However that is history. We are here today and we are about to face another election campaign. The people of Canada should in no way, shape or form think that we are running away from this flawed document.
This free trade agreement is a flawed document. The records show that unfettered, unreviewed foreign investment in this country is not working. Statistics Canada and all the government agencies will show that beyond a shadow of a doubt.
The member for Ontario, for whom I have a lot of respect, said that we on this side of the House have a great capacity to deceive. Well, I want to let the member know that he is right when he cites that there are some winners in this free trade agreement. We have never run away from the fact that there are some winners. But there are a lot more losers and those losers tend to be the smaller and medium-sized manufacturers in this country. I too, like him, was a businessman. I worked for one of the most successful organizations in this country, Magna International. Eighty percent of our business was exports to the United States in auto parts.
We had a very productive labour force and they still have a very productive labour force and they are doing very well. Large companies like Magna, Dow and Dupont-I give them respect for this-only represent about 25 per cent of the employment in this country. A majority of the employment in this country is with the smaller and medium-sized businessman.

Right now this free trade agreement is not serving that sector of our economy. It is not serving it well at all. We have a situation right now where we have a crisis of confidence in this country because not only do we have 1.5 million unemployed and another two million on welfare, but those with jobs are afraid they are about to lose them.
Therefore, when the member talks about the benefits of free trade, he would be wise, in my opinion, to admit yes, there are some winners. He was the one who said there was a capacity to deceive. He should also admit that under this agreement there are losers.
